projectDesc.p: Established in 2010, the goals of the Emma B. Andrews Diary Project include the transcription and digitization of a wide range of primary historical material from the 'Golden Age' of Egyptian archaeology at the end of the 19th and beginning of the 20th centuries. A founding partner of Newbook Digital Texts (www.newbookdigitaltexts.org), the EBA Diary Project offers undergraduate and graduate digital humanities education and internships at the University of Washington. Emma B. Andrews is best remembered for her association with the millionaire lawyer turned archaeologist/art and antiquities collector, Theodore M. Davis. Traveling to Egypt with him between 1889 and 1912, she kept detailed journals of these voyages along the Nile, including his important yet under-reported excavations of over 20 significant tombs in the Valley of the Kings. Emma provides a vital commentary on the archaeology and pioneering Egyptologists of the time, painting a revealing picture of the lives of the colonial gentry and the cultural and scientific literati in at the dawn of the twentieth century. Analysis of the content of her diaries, along with a broad range of additional primary source material, will afford scholars information about important historical resources for the first time.

div.p: Sailed from New York, Saturday November 16th on S.S. Bourgogne, and arrived at Havre Nov. 24th at noon. A dull and uneventful voyage - and a most disagreeable landing in a heavy storm of wind and rain, in a tug, with no protection but that our umbrellas and wraps gave us. Came to our old quarters at Hotel Chatham.

We left Paris on the 5th at 8.30 a.m. for Marseilles. I had been suffering with a severe cold, and confined to the house and often to my room during our stay in Paris. The weather was raw and cold all the time, and the day of our journey to Marseilles was very cold - and the ride seemed excessively long and tiring. We spent a night at the "Hotel du Louvre et de la Paix" at Marseilles, and took a drive the next morning through the streets and along the quays - a cold wind blowing. There had just passed over France, or rather the south of France, one of the worst mistrals ever known and houses in Avignon and Nismes blown down, ships unable to enter or leave the port or Marseilles for days, snow at Nice etc. so that our disappointment in regard to seeing Avignon, Nismes and Arles, which we had planned to do on our way down to Marseilles, and which my illness prevented, was mitigated.

We sailed in the "Gironde" of the Massagieres Maritime line, at 4 o'clock in the afternoon. The boat proved an excellent one -- good service, table and rooms. We found among the passengers Miss Sara Gibbs of Newport. The first night out was excessively cold and rough -- and I went early to bed, grasping my hot water bag, and soon forgot the discomforts. The next morning we had a summer sea to sail over, and we were passing between Corsica and Sardinia, and with a glass could distinguish the houses on either island. In the afternoon we were approaching the Straits of Messina, and a lovely scene it was! For a time it seemed impossible to decide which was the main shore, and which was Sicily -- and we were apparently steaming dead into the rocky shore of the Aspromonte promontory. Everyone was on deck gazing at the beautiful and interesting shores, soon the Strait defined itself, each shore near enough to see the houses plainly without glasses. A heavy mass of clouds hung about the volcanic island of Stromboli, one of the Lipari group, and over Sicily, and Aetna could not be seen, as we struck straight off across the Mediterranean under the Italian shore, for Alexandria, which we reached the evening of the 11th early. We were a long time landing - Mary absorbed and delighted at the novel costumes and appearance of the natives on the shore. We could not get into our former quarters at the "Khedival Hotel", so went to the "Abbot" where we lunched before taking the train to Cairo, which we reached at 9 o'clock. We came to Shepheards and were soon installed in delightful rooms into which the sun looks all day - and out of our windows we look upon a spacious court, with palms and trop-
ical trees, among which the great black and grey crows are flying and cawing all the time.

We are having a "grey day" for this part of the world - but it seems delightfully summer-like to us, even if our northern winter clothes are comfortable. We were busy this morning settling ourselves in our rooms, after which Theodore and I walked to Cook's office, a short distance from the hotel, and looked at plans of steamers and talked over the voyage of the Nile. After an excellent luncheon we drove out, taking Miss Gibbs with us over the Ghèsireh road - it looking almost as natural to us as the Ocean Drive at Newport, - the Kasr-el-Nil bridge, and the drives, all with the same strange motley crowd coming and going, human beings and animals. As a "first sight" there is perhaps nothing to equal it in all the world - and Miss Gibbs and Mary were in constant ecstatic exclamation, while Theodore and I though familiar with it, were impressed, and felt it rather strange and interesting that we should have familiar recollections of Egypt.

Our faithful Mohammed Salah had appeared early in the morning, and been duly engaged, and was occupying his customary seat on the box beside the coachman - his kindly brown face and grave dignified manner, just the same as of old.

We all drove down to the Nile this morning to see the "Sethi" having a permission from Cooks - a cold wind was blowing, and blinding clouds of dust flying. We were not pleased with the appearance of the
: little steamer - I stayed at home alone in the afternoon with my troublesome cold - it cannot be induced to leave me. We talked over the Nile journey and decided to go on the Sethi the 1st of January.

Nowhere I believe can a more brilliant and interesting scene of its kind be found, than the great dining room at Shepheards. A new one has been lately added to the house, large lofty capable of seating 300 people I should judge, with masses of tropical palms and plants in groups against the white walls - People from every quarter of the globe are seated at its tables - ladies in evening dress, as well as travelling dress - and the scarlet coats of many trim swell English officers, and an occasional fez or turban, giving color to it all.

Everyone complains of the bad wintry weather here - and it is I suppose unusual for Egypt. But it seems curious to us - for a hot sun shines most of the time, flowers are blooming in profusion, and we have our windows open all day. There is a good deal of dust from this light soil - If the houses were only built with some provision for indoor comfort in cool weather, it would be charming. Open chimneys for fire and ventilation would make them most comfortable. But it has been stupid work for me during the past week, sitting at home with my cold, when everything is so delightful out of doors.

One morning we went to the carpet bazaar and Theodore bought two or three rugs - after the usual absurd bargaining. The man demanded £106. for the lot. Theodore took out his little book and made
: some figures and promptly offered £28 and got them!

A day of steady hard rain for hours - Mary and Miss Gibbs went bravely off to church - I, of course am condemned to the house - I had a visit from Dr. Murison, and busied myself writing letters. Mohammed Salah appeared at breakfast, with the huge inevitable bouquet, and a remarkable structure in sweets which he called a "Christmas cake", and which I put by for afternoon and asked Sir Frederick and Lady Hughes and Miss Gibbs to come in, and so disposed of it.

We have decided against the steamer -- first Miss Gibbs backed down -- then they went to look at dahabeahs, and became at once infatuated, and after visits to many Theodore decided upon the "Nubia" belonging to Prince Achmed, an iron boat, with an excellent reputation for speed, and with pretty fittings, and very good beds. Her model and fittings were so superior to those of any others that we saw, that in spite of her high price, Theodore decided upon her. Mohammed went at once delightedly to work, and is now very busy with his preparations for our departure, and is arranging for our comfort in a thousand ways. One of my special cares at present is to prevent him from making a financial ruin of himself, as he insists upon buying too many things and too much of everything for us. We hope to get off on Saturday, if a favorable wind blows.

: We had an early breakfast yesterday morning, during which M. Salah appeared and said there would be a wind at eleven o'clock, and the sooner we settled ourselves on the Dahabeah the better it would be. We took this declaration on faith, for the fog and damp and cold outside to our unpractised eyes did not promise much. However Georgette had packed all our belongings, and we were more or less ready - our own trunks, and innumerable big hampers, mysterious rolls of wraps and carpets, were all piled in the hall by our doors, and Mary and I rushed off to two or three shops near the hotel to buy some last necessary things and when we got back we found two big carriages standing in front of the hotel, and our belongings were being stowed away in them and a cart by half a dozen smiling Arabs, who I found were members of our crew. We had invited yesterday Sir Frederick and Lady Hughes, and Miss Gibbs to lunch with us on the boat, provided a favorable wind did not arrive before lunch hour. It was arranged to send the carriage back for the Hughes if this did not occur. We made our adieux to our obliging landlord, and others, and were soon driving over Kasr-el-Nil, and through the market place beyond. It was so delightfully exhilerating to be thus starting out into the unknown, in the midst of so much pleasant preparation. Our driver carefully picked his way between groups of kneeling camels, and flocks of buffalo, sheep and children - then through the narrow streets of the village beyond, between the walls of the low mud houses, their occupants mostly lying or squatting on the ground in front of them. At last we came to the
river, and the dahabeah, proudly floating the stars and stripes from her mast - and all about her a great bustle of preparation, with half the population of the Arab settlement squatted on the sand in front of her in observant silence. Everything was spick and span upon the Nubia - and a smiling welcome from Captain and crew - and so many brown helping hands held out, one could scarcely make a motion. Growing plants upon the upper deck, and flowers inside - and our trunks and belongings all in place. By this time a wind began to get up, and with it came Miss Gibbs to say good bye, and a bunch of lovely roses for me. She had time but for a few words and exclamations at our pretty homelike air, for she had to make the bridge before the "draw" opened at 12 o'clock. Very soon the crew began their preparations for sailing, and the wind having freshened very much, Theodore told Mahomet Salah that we were ready - he replied that "two sailor men had gone ashore to get some tin" - but that if they did not turn up when we were ready to start, we would not wait, as they would run along the bank ahead of us, and we would pick them up - which we did afterwards - one poor fellow with two big tin pans or tubs running about 5 miles before he overtook us. Before we got one big sail out the noon gun from the Citadel fired, and a dahabeah near us, flying the German flag, pulled out before us, however when we got out in the river and caught the wind we soon sailed past her, and Mahommed Salah repeated his assurances that the Nubia was the fastest boat on the river, and we found ourselves slipping rapidly past the dismal prison,
with its gangs of convicts chained to another at work on the bank, past the various palaces lining each side of the river - past the island of Rhoda - past groves of palms - Arab villages - wastes of sand, until we pull up to take on board our belated sailor - here, the German boat which we have dubbed "The Flying Dutchman" overtook us and passed, but we soon caught up with her, left her behind and lost sight of her, until one of our small boats which we carry behind containing our poultry yard of chickens and pigeons, came to grief in some way, and was overturned, and all the poor fowls drowned. I was sorry for M. Salah, it being such a loss to his larder - but he took it with the stoical submission of a true Mahommedan. Again we had to pull up - catch the boat and right it - some of the fowls not being dead, we were astonished to see them throw overboard all of those just drowned, as it seemed they would prove most welcome food at least to the sailors, who so rarely get the opportunity to eat meat - but we learned that the Mahommedans will not eat meat that is not killed and bled. Again the Flying Dutchman passed us. The wind increased very much, and blew hard and strong, and we flew along at the rate of six miles an hour against the current, thus verifying the character of the Nubia. We passed Helouan in the distance, a fashionable health resort, and through a dip in the Mokattam hills, caught a last glimpse of the slender minarets of the Citadel. We passed Bedrashyn where one of Cook's boats was lying on its way up the Nile, with dozens of white helmetted tourists just returned from Memphis and Sakkarah. Then all the Pyramids began to unfold themselves to our delighted eyes - first those of
Ghizeh - then the Sakkarah group with its stepped pyramid - the blunted outline of Aboesir, then Dashoor with its strange curving side, then Meydoum with its three shelved pyramid. A lovely sunset finished the bright day, so full of novelty and pleasure - and the young moon about 5 days old made the night, when it had descended, brilliant.

Our first dinner was a great success - the table very pretty with its candles, and the white, green and gold china. We had been told of the prowess of our cook - and here was a luxurious dinner, admirably cooked, worthy of a chef - we all exclaimed that if we were going to live in this manner for two months we would go off of the dahabeah a party of hopeless dyspeptics. We played a game of cribbage after dinner, and late in the evening, M. Salah came in saying that we were just overtaking the Flying Dutchman, and we rushed on deck to see her lights as we flew past her. I went to bed with great comfort in my big state room, and the last sound I heard was Theodore pacing the deck above me. The wind was so strong and favorable we continued sailing all night with the exception of an hour or two.

This, Sunday morning, I was awakened about 7 o'clock by the stir of getting under way again. After our good breakfast we went on deck to enjoy the fascinating scene - but the light breeze soon increased almost to a gale - and I was first driven below, soon followed by the rest, quite blown to pieces. We had to take in one aft sail, and furl part of our glorious gib main sail, which with its great towering billowing white breast makes our Nubia look like some living thing. It
was very exciting seeing the management of the boat, and the shifting of the big boom. After making splendid progress for some hours, the Captain thought it best to pull up under the lee of a high bank near Benisoef - and here we stayed for 3 hours - the Flying Dutchman presently came tearing along and pulled into the bank also - but she only stayed to furl her big sail, and put up the small one, and was off again - but as we are not in a breathless hurry, we decided to wait for the wind to go down, so that we might sail in comfort. Benisoef is 73 miles from Cairo, and M. Salah says our run of 12 hours from Cairo here, is the best one he ever made, and he has been 20 years on the river. Miss Edwards in "A Thousand Miles"" etc., says they took 10 days coming here, and were 3 days in getting away.

I stayed below all the day - sitting in the cabin and staring through the windows at the strange, if not attractive scene beside us, of two boats loading with sugar cane - trains of camels coming down over the steep sandy bank and depositing it, and then scrambling back. A number of fellaheen soon made their appearance, and squatted down in the sand to look at us. A group of mother and two children fascinated me. The woman with the usual dark blue dress, dingy with dirt, her arms and neck and fingers covered with ornaments that looked as if they might be gold - the children with merest rags of garments, and covered with flies, hung about her like young animals - the smaller one standing nursing - and tugging at his mother's breast like a young calf. Georgette went outside with some curiosity, and spoke Page 11: to them, but the woman's manner was rather threatening, and she moved away with her children. Two of the men had distaffs which they twirled diligently, making thread - above on the bank, beyond the forest of grandly waving palms, a mile or two away, lay the village of Benisoef, with 10,000 inhabitants, and a sheik of its own. About 3 o'clock we pushed off, flying the merest little handkerchief of a sail with the wind lulled, and we went on under the big sail until about 8 o'clock, when the Captain sent word through M. Salah, that he would like to tie up for the night - that there "was one big mountain" and the current bad. We were soon made fast to the bank - the crew had enclosed their deck with canvas - a lantern was swung, rugs and blankets taken out - and they gathered about the mutual supper bowl - afterwards taking out their curious drums and tambourines, and giving us our first concert, strange droning music in a minor key.

The wind was so high last night, that we laid quietly by until an early hour this morning. After breakfast I went out on deck, and basked in the delicious sunlight, interested in everything I saw, until the wind became so strong I came below. Behind us we saw the sand storm coming, and our little aft sail is ordered to be furled - the waves are really high, the sand obscures the shore, and we are tearing along at a tremendous pace. I hear below the confusion above, the shouting of orders and shrieks of the wind, and it is very exciting - but we cannot stop, and not make any use of this wind, so we
keep on with a little rag of a sail, and at 12 o'clock pass Magraghah, 106 miles from Cairo, making this distance in two days, in spite of our frequent stopping. At one o'clock the captain sent word that he would rather stop until the wind fell a little - which we were very glad to hear, as we were able to eat our lunch in peace. The sailors made us fast to the high black mud bank, and M. Salah reported a town not far off - but the sand was blowing so, that none of us had the courage to attempt walking. Theodore took to his stateroom for a sleep - and Mary and Georgette clambered up the bank, and over it a little way, and came back with a bunch of mustard flowers, and some white clover blossoms, and a new and beautiful kind of grass. Numbers of lovely white and gray birds were flying about - much like our sand pipers. About 4 o'clock the wind fell and we pushed off, flying only the little sail from the felucca. I stayed down in the cabin all the afternoon perched up on one of the divans near a window, watching the shifting scenes on either side sometimes with a glass, of mud banks and villages, of palm fringed shores, of sterile sandy hills - the women eternally filling their water jugs, and walking off in stately grace, with these balanced on their heads - the storks standing about on their longs legs. Never shall I forget that picture I saw - a perfect silhouette against a clear yellow sunset sky - of a group streaming along the high bank - two or three women and children - a man on a donkey, with a child behind him - another young donkey full of life and pranks kicking up his heels behind him - then a dog and three or four sheep, all streaming along the narrow path - showing perfectly black against
the orange sky. Inside in our pretty cabin, was such perfect quiet and repose, the little kerosene stove that we bought at Theodore's suggestion in Cairo, and that has proved such a jewel, making a real fireside glow over everything - I threw myself down on the divan in a mood of deepest content, and fell asleep, until Theodore and Mary came down half frozen from the upper deck; for we find the mornings and evenings really cold, and I find my fur cloak comfortable. I may now I think describe our dahabeah, and her belongings - in which we are so comfortable, that it is a delight to think it must last two months - and one wonders if it is possible that during that time we can ever become, after the manner of the average tiresome human being, weary of it, or find anything to complain of! We find the boat everything and more, than we expected - It is very clean, and in good order - the beds are delightfully comfortable, and all the arrangements are very good - my room, which occupies the stern, is really palatial, with its two beds, one of which we use for a lounge, its two big arm chairs, its chest of drawers with the mirror above, the little reading table at the head of my bed, and all the space, to say nothing of my nice little dressing room! The other staterooms, 3 in number are equally good, though smaller, and there is beside a room for Mahommed S. Our cabin, which serves as both dining room and sitting room, is about 12 x 15 , with a bookcase, two side boards with mirrors above, divans on each side, easy chairs etc. The prevailing color of all the fittings of the boat, is the "Prophet's" own - a bright grass green - an odious color to our ideas, but which has the merit of bright-
ness and cheerfulness - and there are besides, white linen covers for everything. Quite a pretty carpet with small figures in green and brown, covers all this part of the boat, and curtains and portiers and divans are covered with green silk brocade. We have decorated the cabin with some embroideries bought the other day at the Cairo bazaar, and with some of our own things put about, we l ook very homelike. Beyond the cabin are the pantries and dragoman's room, and from the hall between, you go up three steps to the level of the lower deck - where the crew live and sleep, and wash and iron, and bake and brew - and in the lockers under which all their belongings, and many of our stores are kept. Near the end of this deck rises the main mast, carrying its great boom - and beyond this, the tiniest and most wonderful little kitchen that can be imagined - with blue and white tiles - and the wonder is, how all the delicious and skillful dishes that we make way with from morning to night can be concocted in that little place. The upper deck is reached by two narrow stair cases or gangways, from the lower deck - but before mounting those stairs I must not omit a description of the crew's kitchen - which consists of a stove just big enough to hold a soup pot, and it stands just to one side of the main mast - the little cook who presides over this is an Arab boy I should think of fourteen years - besides being cook for the crew, he is generally useful I see - and is ready to fetch and carry to any one's call - and is the sailor who climbs up to the extreme length of the big boom - and looks very much when he is there
like a large black fly. The greater part of the upper deck forms our principal sitting room, and is gay and comfortable with the handsome rugs Theodore bought at the Cairo bazaar the other day, and has two cushioned sofas with big pillows, a table and easy chairs - the stern part of the deck is sacred to the steersman, who with the Captain sleeps there. Behind the dahabeah we carry in our wake two small boats - the felucca as the one for our use is called, and another as I said before, in which we carry our live stock - and in the early morning I get the benefit in my room, of the dispirited crows and cackling of the imprisoned fowls. Our crew consists of our captain or Rais, who is always sitting or standing at the head of one of the gangways - he wears a long black gown which drags on the ground, and the big loose sleeves of which fall over his hands - a red tarboosh, with a white embroidered scarf wound round it as a turban, and is distinguished by his white woolen stockings and red leather shoes, these last I fancy being assumed for dignity or appearance, as I have come across him again and again in his moments of unbending and relaxation and have invariably surprised him with his shoes set side by side in a formal manner near his feet. In the cool of the morning and evening he ties a soft white woolen shawl about his head and shoulders, and looks from the rear like some respectable old lady going out to spend the afternoon in cloak and hood. He is a Nubian - oldish - quite black, or bronze rather - has a very quiet and watchful manner, is never excited - and
rules his crew with much quiet decision. He can say "good morning" and a few other words in English, but is very shy of it. He has a most powerful looking fellow for Steersman or Second Captain, and 10 sailors, mostly Nubians, who all seemed to me at first to look exactly alike, but who are now beginning to assume some individual features - but I still wonder if I shall ever know them by name, or distinguish them apart. They all seem gentle, patient fellows and when I go out they all spring to give me a helping hand up the stairs, and I am sustained to the very top by three or four of them, and then Mahommed Salah or the Captain receive me from their hands as if I were an imbecile. It is too absurd - but I endure it because I fear if I protest against it I will be misunderstood. Theodore and Mary indulge in much raillery on the subject. Then there is our cook - a middle aged fine looking Copt, Hannah Ibraim by name, to whom we owe so many comforts - he is assisted by what M. S. calls a "cook maid", a black fellow in red fez and yellow cotton gown. Then comes the indoor servants - Hassan, a cousin of Mohammed S.'s in regulation dragomans dress, who though an honest fellow, seems the only stupid disagreeable man on board, and his assistant, another of the innumerable Mahommeds, who is one of our laundresses - as well as chambermaid - and over all, our faithful Mahommed Salah. This is our personnel.

A soft and brilliant morning sun shone into the windows of
my room and dressing room - and the glimpses of the lovely shores on either side kept me a long time dressing. After breakfast we all went up stairs and stayed until lunch was ready - it was a most delicious morning until about 11 o'clock the wind grew very strong bringing the sand with it, and again we had to sail under the small felucca sail. We passed Gebel-et-Sayr (the mountain of birds) with its lovely palm groves, and Coptic Convent, and desolate frowning cliffs - and two wretched fellows ran along the bank, clamouring for baksheesh, and shouting that they were Christians like ourselves, and dropping their fluttering rags, plunged into the water and swam to the boat, and were starting to climb up, when M.S. - who is strong on the decencies of life, yelled and shouted after them and made them drop back into the cold water - not however until they had secured in their mouths, the two shillings Theodore gave them. We passed Minieh about 2 o'clock - making 156 miles from Cairo in 3 days - a very remarkable run. Opposite Minieh, were moored four dahabeahs, three of them flying the American flag, and the fourth, the Union Jack. They had all left Cairo some days before us. Our Rais talked of stopping for again there was "one big mountain" and difficult bends and currents - but we urged him on, and as the others were making ready to sail, we did not stop. The wind continued high, and all the rest of the afternoon the five boats were streaming along the great bends of the river here, more or less together, forming a pretty spectacle. This evening we are all lying one behind another about 4 miles from Beni Hassan. I have been on Page 18: deck for a few minutes - a radiant moon in a cloudless sky is shining down on this strange scene - the stars are brilliant - Orion striding right across the heaven above us. Crouched around a fire of corn stalks on the bank, is our guard sent from the town, of four men - for this is a dangerous neighborhood - they are smoking and talking in a low voice, and I see the gleaming of the moonlight on the barrels of their rifles. The lights from the other boats behind us, and their watch fires and smoking guards, made quite a scene against this desolate coast. There was much visiting between the crews - and the drumming, and tinkling of the tambourines, and the singing, made quite a gayety. This is the last day of the old year!

While dressing this morning, I saw quite a concourse of men, children and donkeys gathered on the bank before us, who had supposed that we must be intending to visit the grotto tombs of Beni Hassan - but we have decided to leave these until we come down. Several of the children were holding up curious little things, which I did not at first recognize as mummied cats. Some of them were comically like, and I sent Georgette to tell M. Salah to buy, which he did, for half a franc apiece! They smelled so loud, that I begged M.S. to stow them away somewhere for me. I found the side-board graced by a remarkable structure of cake and sweetmeats, which the cook had compounded the night before, in honor of our New Years Day. Our greetings from the
crew and from all the men were most hearty - some of them being able to say a word or two in English - and they broke into a ringing shout when M.S. announced that Theodore would give them a sheep on our arrival at Assiout - and gave him in return something like a three times three. It is the custom during the Nile voyage to give the sailors a sheep on three or four occasions. It means a great deal to them, and is probably the only time in the year when they get any meat to eat. They are such gentle patient people - working so cheerfully from morning to night - their wants are few, and their habits simple - they eat little, of the most simple food - about four times in the day - and each meal is invariably like every other, with the exception that sometimes a few raw onions are taken with it, or two or three leaves of a coarse kind of salad. Their food is a coarse bread cut in slices, and dried in the sun for days, until it is quite brown, when it is broken up and mixed with a soup of lentils - and they eat it from one big wooden bowl, with spoons, about which they all gather squatting on their haunches. If one of them wants a drink, he leans over the side of the boat and scoops up a tin full of water - they generally wash their hands after eating, and many of them rinse their mouths. After their last meal of the day they smoke a pipe called hubble-bubble - one pipe serving for all, and handed from one person to another. Then they get out their drums and tambourines and sing, until one after the other rolls himself in his blanket, somewhere on the deck for the night. It seems a hard life - and what these poor
folk must think of the endless variety of dishes they daily see carried into our cabin, and the countless things that are necessary to our comfort, I cannot imagine. We have had a magnificent sailing wind all day - indeed it was sometimes too strong. Again I took refuge in our bright, comfortable cabin until late in the afternoon when the wind having fallen, I went on deck for an hour before sunset - it was deliciously calm and beautiful - a number of working boats all along the river, with their picturesque loads of Arabs and merchandises. We landed for the night just before dusk, and the rest went for a walk along the shore, and came in late for dinner. We have made today about 30 miles. We have passed Rhodah, where the Khedive has extensive sugar factories - and Tel-Amarna where there are grotto tombs of great interest, belonging to the 18th Dynasty - and are now just approaching the great chain of mountains which stretch precipitously along the east bank of the river for 10 - 12 miles - known as Gebel Abou-Faydak.

The thermometer this morning at 8:30 marked 49º - and it seemed to me it might be even colder, so cold was it in my room when I wakened, in spite of the glow from the little stove. The sky was overcast with clouds too. I sat shivering in the cabin after breakfast for an hour, then the sun coming out I went up on deck. If it had been possible to have escaped the wind the sun would have been too hot. The wind failed however after a time, and the men took to polling, and
later to tracking. Late in the afternoon a good breeze carried us on our way into the evening, when we struck a sand bank, but soon got away, and anchored in mid river for the night. All day we have been passing the great cliffs of the Gebel Aboufaydah chain - at Manfalout they rise abruptly from the water. These limestone cliffs, like all the long range almost unbroken that has followed us from Cairo, are honey combed with tombs that look like little caves. I have been putting out my eyes staring at them through the glass. I could make out two or three real portals, and occasionally a pillar or rough paintings - sometimes men could be seen on the face of the cliffs, quarrying stones. We are about 11 miles from Assiout.

This morning was bright and beautiful - yet the thermometer marked 45º. We found ourselves opposite the southern extremity of the Gebel Aboufaydah range - where are situated the famous grottoes of Maabdeh - filled with thousands and thousands of mummied crocodiles - and some human mummies, which are decorated most richly. I hear that these caves have been very little explored. The cliffs of this range used to be the favorite resort of crocodiles - and Mary has been on the alert, for she intends to see a crocodile frequently - though they have not been seen for years below Assouan. The steamers, and the tourists with their guns have frightened them all away.

The river makes some great bends here, and it was tedious even in the fair wind we had for we see the minarets of Assiout, now here now there, and we never seemed to come nearer, until at last we left the cliffs, and were approaching Assiout - a large important town of 30,000 inhabitants, and the terminus of the railway from Cairo. It is 250 miles from Cairo, and we have made the distance in the extraordinary time of 6 days - and we sing aloud our praises of the "Nubia". The landing place is gay as we pull up to it, with two Cooks steamers, with their red flags and pennants - and several dahabeahs. We were no sooner fast, than the donkeys and donkey boys began to assemble themselves together, ready to pounce upon their prey - for, whenever a dahabeah is seen approaching the news immediately spreads - and every man who has a donkey to ride, or a fowl or sheep or eggs or whatnot to sell, hastens with them to the landing. When the saddles were brought out of the hold on the lower deck, they made for us, and even invaded the deck, and attempted to seize the saddles. Our crew were not enough for them, and it took M.S. and Gens d'armes with their sticks to keep them in order. While M.S. was selecting the donkeys, and the saddles were being put on, there was a dire confusion of yells and blows - but the choice being once made sudden peace fell - and the disappointed ones decamped quietly enough. M.S. had caused a chair to be especially constructed for me before we left Cairo (of which he is immensely proud) should riding be too hard for me. I have felt very dubious about this chair from the first, and when four of our men marched
off with it, I must say it gave us the air of a funeral cortige. I got bravely upon a donkey, and the men with the chair struck across the fields to the town, to be in reserve for me, and we started for the town 3 miles away, for some distance riding between the R.R. tracks, then on a fine high road past some beautiful gardens and pretentious houses, and entered the outskirts of the town - which generally had all the wretched features of the usual eastern town - squalor and dirt and misery - the sightless eyes - the filthy children - the men squatting or lying in heaps of rags against the walls. The bazaar was the most interesting one I had seen, in its general features. We stopped at one of the boutiques, and bargained for some of the frail but pretty pottery for which Assiout is famous. I was very anxious to replace as exactly as possible the pretty black coffee pot dear Annie Freudenberg brought me from here years ago - but I could see nothing like it. When we were almost through the bazaar M.S. who seemed to think I was neglecting his chair, proposed that I should get in it, which I did; but instead of being carried by the poles, as in the ordinary chaise-à-porteur, I was raised aloft, and the handles were borne on their shoulders! to the great amusement of the rest of our party, and the consternation of the crowded bazaar, who fell away before me as if I were an eastern potentate, or the Queen of Sheba. Our men were delighted, as they always enjoy a show of dignity in those they serve - and I felt like the car of Juggernaut as they swept the crowd from my path, and when I saw them spinning a poor blind man almost off his feet, I could ******** (? upon these people, in their manner of living and thinking.

Mr Anderson seemed an intelligent, sensible man, with pleasant manners - and Mrs. A's fresh complexion did not seem to have suffered anything from her 15 years residence in this climate. They have 5 bright, healthy looking children. The big lofty room - with its homely decorations - its American stove, its prints of George and Martha Washington - the Bible texts framed and hung about the room, and a sewing machine piled high with half finished little frocks, all told of housewifely care and order, and seemed such a domestic, wholesome bit in that eastern environment, that it pleased me much. We bought a Bible, for we have only a french one with us, and promising to call on our way down the river, we said goodbye, and mounted our donkeys, turning our faces homeward. Meeting a stream of tourists walking and riding, and we concluded Cook's' new steamer the "Rameses"" had arrived - and on reaching the river bank we found the landing below crowded. I was glad to dismount from the wise looking little "Mahomet Ali" I had been riding all the afternoon, through the wind and the dust, and reach the quiet of our bright little cabin and the comfort of hot water and brushes. Hassan had the tea table ready, and the smoking Samovar and a loaf of fresh plum cake looked inviting. Just as we began taking our tea General Stauring and his party came in from the Rameses, and were loud in praise of the comfort and homelike air of our dahabeah - and made many a complaint of their fellow passengers on the steamer. In the evening we amused ourselves looking at our pretty jars, and
congratulated ourselves that we were not "Cookites", and we decided to push on in the morning, if this strong wind holds - and leave the rest of Assiout for our return. The tombs on the mountains are not very much, but the view from there is said to be one of the finest in Egypt. We learn that an English dahabeah lying here took 23 days from Cairo here!

A grey day with little sunshine, and much cold wind. I did not once go on deck - and spent much of the day in reading the piles of newspapers that came by mail to us yesterday. We have made a splendid run, and are yet sailing, and expect to make 50 miles before we stop for the night. The almost unbroken mountain chain on the east bank continues its limestone stata almost perfectly level, and its sky line equally so. In places the river has scooped itself a great bend around the vast sand banks it has deposited - and we leave the mountains only to come back almost to the same place, after hours of sailing - along the low sand banks are troops and troops of birds - about which no one can give me information. M.S. calls them all eagles when I ask him. I stare at them through the glass, and enjoy the spectacle. The vultures are the funniest things - sitting in solemn rows - and looking too ridiculous - and the storks standing about on one of their long legs, and a strange heavy looking fowl, brown and black, with a small head and wide spreading wings - and everywhere the cheer-
ful little water wag-tail - who invade our decks - sit about on the ropes, and complain to us that we give them nothing to eat - occasionally one will hop along the rugs, directly to our feet.

In the afternoon hearing a stir outside, I got up from my divan where I was having a little siesta, and saw a group of running scrambling children, and a dog, running along the bank to which we were very close, to whom Theodore and the men were throwing bread and apples and such a rough and tumble scramble as it was! One little fellow was the veriest bundle of rags ever seen - his naked body showing through everywhere - how he could keep them on was a mystery - one boy had not even a rag, and was ready to plunge into the water any moment, if the prize failed to reach the shore. The other boy was deterred I suppose from the fear of spoiling his clothes! The dog got the greater share, which the children took good naturedly - In the evening as the full moon was shining resplendently, we came close to the lofty cliffs of Gebel Sheykh Heréedee, in some places rising abruptly from the water. Just at the bend of the river, was a narrow strip of land, crowded with great palm trees - making a most enchanting scene - and here about 8 o'clock, we tied up for a time, waiting for the wind to lull, before we attempted passing this "one big mountain". M.S. reports this part of the river very dangerous, because of the thieves and lawless inhabitants of the country - and tells a thrilling story, which we heard ourselves in Assiout yesterday, how a few days ago, a lot of them went into that town, robbing and killing 3 or 4 men.

We have had our first adventure! The night being so fine, we sailed late - and I had been roused by the noise made over my head by the sailors, and for a long time could not sleep - and lying half awake, I was suddenly roused by an unusual noise in the water like something rushing close to us, and a little bump. After considering whether I should get up and call Theodore, I decided at least to light my candle, and in the same moment I heard the steersman above me jump up with a warning shout, and instantly there was a babel of voices and cries. When I got my door open, I found Theodore just coming out of his room in his bathing gown, and saw M.S. rushing out on the deck with his revolver. Theodore stopped to get into an ulster, and followed him. Mary and Georgette appeared from their rooms and we breathlessly awaited developments. Three shots fired hastily sounded very alarming at that time of night, but it turned out that no one at least on our boat was hurt. The steersman discovered a boat crowded with Arabs stealing close to us - and I clearly heard her touch. When the alarm was given, and all our men showed themselves, and demanded as I suppose in choice Arabic expletives what they meant, they pulled hastily away, and declared they had mistaken us for an Arab boat, which they wished to board. A flimsy excuse so M.S. thought, and so sent three shots from his revolver after them. It took us some little time to compose ourselves, though Theodore made light of it, and seemed to think the men had been easily alarmed. But I think they know
their own country better than we do - and the reports of the turbulent state of this part of the country would seem to be true, after the occurrence at Assiout the other day. At any rate Mary and I prefer to think that the blood thirsty villains wanted our money and our lives, and that we made a narrow escape!
Theodore gave orders to stop at the first good ground, and we pulled up about 1 o'c. and I fancy a double watch was kept for the rest of the night.

All day long we have been spanking along before the high wind. Theodore and M.S. continually exchanging compliments on the fine sailing qualities of the "Nubia". The villages are growing very picturesque. We have passed several large populous towns - Sohag, with a population of 8700 - with mosques and minarets - and Girgeh, with a lovely minaret. All of these towns are built on the site of, or near ancient ruins and tombs, most interesting to an archaeologist. They all have the most singular buildings or towers, which are really pigeon houses - and the pigeons in this part of the country must be numbered by millions. These towns are lofty - somewhat pyramidal in shape, and have very curious rounded looking battlements, each one of which is a pigeon house. Very often, these towers surmount the houses - and dried twigs and branches are fastened on their sides, for convenient roosting places. I have often seen them in photographs, but could never discover what they were. These pigeons are not for eating, and no one is allowed I believe to kill them. They are kept for their manure, which is
carefully collected, dried and pressed into flat cakes, and used for fuel, and is very valuable. We had another incident this afternoon - one of the men fell overboard from the boom, they say he was not hurt, but he got an unexpected bath. I opened the door to see what the matter was, and found him just scrambling on the boat again - and he began to take off his clothes so rapidly, that I did not stop to make inquiries. We passed on the east a chain of hills that came down close to the river, known as Gebel Tookh - when I first noticed them we were just at their base - and looking up their lofty slope the sky above them was of the softest and most exquisite deep purple blue - the little strip of water dividing us from the cliff was almost as blue - nothing but these two pure shades to be seen - the blue, and the soft yellow of the limestone hills! and their conformation was so remarkable. I longed for a geologist to tell me about them. They bore evident marks of running water, and were worn into great rounded bastions and buttresses and clustered pillars - and over all, cropping out over the limestone strata is a curious looking stalactite formation. We brought up at Balliana for the night, having made 56 miles since morning! This is the place from which Abydos is visited - but we defer this until we come down.

We put off from Ballianeh very early yesterday morning in a fine wind - but it grew lighter and lighter until about 1 o'clock we were left "a painted ship" upon the water. Then we wished we had
given the day to Abydos. The wind not only gave out for a time, but veered to the south, and we had to throw out an anchor. We caught up and passed the Flying Dutchman, however, before this, and have kept each other in sight ever since - for today has been much like yesterday with only less wind - and what with tracking and polling, we have only made 5 miles, whereas yesterday we made 26. The day has been delicious really hot - and we had up an awning for the first time, and I doffed my fur cloak. The river was a mirror - and from every direction came the melancholy cry of the shadoof workers. The shores are lined with shadoofs - which are simple appliances for raising the water of the river to the level of irrigation. Two poles are set up, four or five feet apart, and several feet above the river - on a cross pole between these is balanced a long pole, weighted at one end by a large mass of dried mud, and from the other is suspended a bucket made of skin or leather. If the river is low, two or three of these are placed one above the other - at each level a basin is scooped out for the reception of the water, and below it stands a man who sinks the bucket in the water, where it is filled, then letting go of it the weight at the other end lifts the bucket of water, which is received by a man on the next level, who empties it either into the irrigating ditch, or into the receptacle above for water. The men are generally naked, except for a cloth about the loins, and look like dripping bronze statues, and they have a peculiar cry as they work, consisting of 3 or 4 notes which we find impossible to get, in a minor key with a peculiar quaver, and the effect is desolate and melancholy in the extreme
and seems the hopeless expression of their joyless and hopeless lives. In the quiet of the evening, it is especially sad, and when the land is at all well cultivated, the shadoofs are only a few yards apart. What an important part the Nile plays in this strange country! aside from its supplying the soil, and being the sole means of cultivation, its mud is so useful - they make their pots and dishes of it, build their houses and fences of it - the upright poles of the shadoofs are generally made of bunches of corn stalk about which the mud is moulded, and soon baked hard and dry in the sun - they use it for mortar and plaster, and it takes the place of wood in dozens of ways.

We started very early this morning polling - and the men making such a noise from necessity, that Theodore gave orders there should be no more polling before 7 o'clock. In spite of light winds and dead calms, we reached Keneh (405 miles from Cairo) about 2 o'clock. We landed opposite the town, and took donkeys for Denderah, half an hours ride away. We crossed the fields "sans ceremonie" - riding over patches of young onions and wheat, crossed the dry bed of a canal, and then followed a little path across pleasant fields. O! how charming it was as we all streamed along there! the bright day - the fragrant air, the strange country - and actually, before my eyes at last, an Egyptian Temple! I knew it from prints and photographs, but as we drew near it, the stupendous façade and gloomy portal, with vistas of enormous, closely set pillars, with their heavy fantastic capitals of Hathor heads,
was sufficiently impressive. I will not attempt any description of it, for I can always find a better one to read than I could write. It is one of the most important and best preserved of the Temples - and the newest. It was begun by Ptolemy XI, and finished under Tiberius and Nero. Marriette Bey says "Jesus Christ was living in Jerusalem when this temple was being completed" and he gives an admirable description of it, and of the allegorical sentiment shown by the sculptures and paintings. We walked about those great halls with their mighty columns like a handful of pigmies, looking at the pictures and reliefs that cover the surface of each wall and column - with here and there the colors still showing. Then climbed the processional stairs, which received only an occasional shaft of light through a square opening in the enormously thick walls. Our guides carried lighted candles, not only that we might see the unbroken line of incised inscriptions and pictures which covered every surface of the dark walls, but that we might see where we were putting our feet, and it gave one a strange sensation to see that in this newest of Egyptian temples, these solid shallow steps were worn in the middle to a smooth level! We came out at last upon the terrace or roof of the temple, where we found a beautiful little hypaethral temple with 12 columns, dedicated to Osiris. Then we clambered to the top of the cornice, and sat down to rest and talk - and read our books of description. We could look down upon the ruins of the great enclosing wall of bricks, that always surrounded an Egyptian Temple, to conceal its mysteries - The stones forming the roof
of the temple, raised a few feet above the level of the terrace were enormous - astounding. Theodore and Mary, after we had descended, went down into the crypt. I had no curiosity for this, even had I been able to climb down those huge steps from 4 to 5 feet high. After they had disappeared there came swarming from the black chasm of a staircase, troops of bats, disturbed by the lights the men were carrying. Our ride home at that hour would have been charming, had it not been for the procession of children, some of them such wee little things, who followed us home to the dahabeah, and would not be shaken off. They pattered along in their little bare feet, running and tumbling over one another, and crying in their pleasant voices, Baksheesh, baksheesh, and holding in their hands for sale everything, from a stalk of mustard in flower, to nuts from the dom palm, and spurious antiques. It was a piteous thing to see that two men over whose crops we were riding and walking, should rush along protesting violently, not at us, but at the poor little bare feet that were hurrying along with us.

Much tracking and polling today, and very little wind. It has been lovely and warm, and we have had an awning up. We have had all day, a large dahabeah flying the American flag, just before us - whose owners no doubt we encountered at Denderah yesterday - and tonight we are tied up very near each other.

Again a day of little wind, and with all the effort we could make, we are only anchored tonight about 12 miles from Luxor - with the big American tied up just behind us, we having succeeded in passing her today as she was stuck on a sand bank. The Flying Dutchman too, is just ahead of us. This morning, as we were lying by a high bank with a luxuriant grove of palm trees, Theodore and M.S. went off for a walk, Mary established herself on the bank to finish the sketch of the dahabeah begun several days ago - and I and Georgette escorted by one of our men carrying a long pole, without which an Arab does not seem able to walk, clambered up the bank for a little stroll. I wanted the pleasure of wandering among the palms, which did not prove all I had hoped for, as all the space between the trees was thick dust. We picked a few unknown flowers, and saw an Egyptian scarab, a large handsome shining black fellow, not engaged in the traditional exercise of rolling his ball of eggs up the bank, as I would have preferred, but foolishly basking in the sun on a dry branch. Georgette called him a "bête" and looked at him with much disgust - but I explained that he was a very celebrated character. We met a lot of women and children and they all put out their hands and said "Backsheesh Hawajis" - the women all seem to have such very sweet pleasant voices. We had got home and were sitting under the awning of the upper deck, when we noticed a little procession coming along the bank - a dignified man riding a donkey, preceeded by several men carrying rifles, and follow-
ed by others. We were astonished to see M.S. stride hastily up the bank, and the man alight at once, and the two went through some ceremonious formalities, then fell upon each other's necks in a truly patriarchial fashion. M.S. then brought him down to the boat, where he was received with much respect by the men - some of the sailors raising his robe to kiss. M.S. then came to us and explained that he was the Sheik bey of the Ababdehs, an important tribe of the Bedouins, and had control of all the country between the Nile and Red Sea. Theodore told M.S. to bring him up to us. He was a grave, kindly splendid looking middle aged man. He merely touched each of us by the hand, and then carried his hand to his forehead, then to his heart, and sat down on one of the divans, and we made a little slow conversation with M.S. as interpreter. But conversation in the East is not considered a necessary adjunct to a visit, or one of the duties of hospitality, and I suppose an Oriental would pronounce the rattling nothings we exchange with one another when we visit, the height of bad manners and vulgarity. It takes a well bred person I always think to sit through an awkward silence with composure, and with no evident effort to think of what to say, and I admired the calm placidity of our guest, and felt that my unconscious mental efforts to cast about for something to say, were very undignified. We had coffee served and Theodore gave him a cigarette. Mary showed him her sketch book in which he seemed interested, and when he saw the excellent sketch of Mohammed so like, he broke into a broad smile, showing all his white teeth. I told M.S. to say to him
that I had read a great deal about the Bedouins and their desert, and wanted very much to make the journey across it, then he bowed and touched his forehead and the region of his heart with inimitable grace and dignity, and said something to the effect, that the desert, and he, and his tribe were at my disposal, when I should arrange to go, and that he hoped very soon etc. etc. Mary photographed him, after asking his permission. And then he said that among his men, he had one of another tribe, that of the Busharin, and he was fetched to be photographed - which he evidently enjoyed, his black little eyes taking in everything with much curiosity - he was of low stature, with a great many yellow white rags hanging about him, quite black, with hair in small thick curls. Finally the Sheik went away across the river in his boat, as, M.S. explained he had a case to try of some "steal people" on the other side of the river.

This morning after almost a dead calm for two or three hours, the wind freshened and we were approaching Luxor, lying on the eastern bank, looking very gay with the flags of the different consulates flying from their respective buildings. The crew had got out their drums and tambourines, and were singing and drumming as they always do when we pull up to a place of any importance. Flags were fluttering too from several dahabeahs, and a Cook's steamer. As we passed a dahabeah with the stars and stripes at the mast, M.S. fired two salutes, which
were answered by her, and a salute from the American Consulate which we returned, so that we made a proper sensation as we moved to our mooring ground, just beyond the Luxor Hotel - we were soon in the felucca, and the man pulling us to the music of their songs, to the Post Office, where we got our mail, and then went to the great temple, at whose beautiful columns we had been staring as we passed. It was begun by Amenophis III (1703 B.C.) and completed by Ramsis II, the irregular colonnades with their singular heavy papyrus columns belongs to the older part. Nothing of great interest about it - it is choked and emcumbered with modern erectures - a mosque, and a bevy of Arab mud houses. Champollion or Rosellini lived in one of these in 1829, and later it was inhabited by Lady Duff Gordon, who spent the last years of her life here - and very sad years they must have, been so far from her home, and husband and children - they must have been full of kindness and usefullness to those around her, and Miss Edwards says, Every Arab in Luxor cherishes her memory in his heart of hearts, and speaks of her with blessings. We paid a short visit to the Luxor Hotel, to see how far it bore out the praises lavished upon it by Cook's pamphlets. The entrance gate is near the landing and we walked through a pleasant avenue of Scent trees, their pretty little tufted yellow flowers making the air fragrant with their delicate perfume. The house looked very attractive and especially the newer portion now occupied by the Grand Duke Peter of Russia and his suite
- and he sat reading on one of the low balconies. The house is built of Nile bricks of mud, with enormously thick walls - and looked comfortable enough, though the rather English styles of everything contrasted strongly with the crude style of building. We sat down in the shade of the verandah to read our letters. I saw several sad faced invalids, walking slowly about the grounds - and a hideous stout old head of an Englishwoman, enveloped in furs, with gold chains and beads and bracelets and rings, sitting in a wheel chair. She was such a type, that I wanted to sit down in front of her and think of her, and talk to her. On one of the low balustrades, was a huge pelican - a magnificent creature, quite tame, and most affectionately devoted to a young pointer dog, who returned the attentions most demonstrably, and it was very comical.

Theodore and Mary then started for the tour of the town, and I and Georgette went back to the felucca, and were rowed most merrily home - and sat on deck watching with great amusement the purchases of M.S. in the commisariat line - turkeys, pigeons and chickens, eggs and milk were arriving, and M.S. and the cook were making their selections undisturbed by the babel of voices about them - but when the financial settlement came, it was something terrific - those who had not sold united their noisy gesticulations with those who had sold, but also had not got so much money as they demanded, our old hag beat her breast, and went through the motions at least of tearing her hair. M.S. and
the Hannah Ibraim, our stately cook, coming quietly on board, with some of our men bringing on the purchases, was the signal for the breaking up of the market, a sudden peace fell, and they all went off chatting and smiling. There is always this scene on these occasions - they are never satisfied with any price they get - there is always this terrifying climax, from which they fall to quiet, cheerful acquiescence - and all depart apparently contented. Much of it comes no doubt, from the singular fatalistic submission of the Mohammedan - we have often noticed this feature in the Mohammedans.

We made 5 miles last evening after leaving Luxor, before we tied up for the night. This morning was very overcast, and it seemed every moment that it would rain. The air was as quiet as the water which was glassy in its stillness. The men have been tracking and polling. In the afternoon we were passing Erment, on the west side of the river, with an important sugar factory - and we saw little steam cars laden with coal, which looked extremely out of place with their environment of palm trees. The quite modern buildings of the town extend along the water side, thickly shaded by lubbek and sycamore - and under one of the widely spreading hoary old sycamore trees, some kind of a court of Justice was sitting - actually squatting on the ground - such an assemblage of turbans, it was! Egypt is the natural home of
the sycamore - their leaves are smaller than with us however, and the foliage much more compact. I have seen numbers of splendid specimens, of which that one forming the roof of that Court of Justice was the finest. Some time after this the wind having freshened very much, and we making a merry progress, we suddenly brought up with a shiver against a sand bank. Such a commotion as followed I have not seen since our midnight adventure. Such cries, and boundings about on deck - and such struggles with the poles! Soon we were off, and wisely decided that as this part of the river is full of sand banks, we would pull up for the night, and here we are in profound stillness, with only the soft lapping of the water against our sides, to break it. Theodore told us of such an amusing little incident he met with in Luxor, he encountered a very small boy, who put out his very small hand and asked for baksheesh, saying: I am a poor man - I hold up my father and mother - I am glad to see you, how do you do? Theodore of course could not resist this funny appeal, and gave him some money - when he said pleasantly "thank you, go to Hell". I fancy many idle tourists amuse themselves teaching English phrases, of not the choicest description to those poor little monkeys, and this is one of the results.

Started with a light wind this morning, which soon failed, and in spite of the heat, the men took to tracking. The day has been entirely overcast, looking as if the rain might fall at any moment,
and giving an effect as of a natural law interfered with as if some strange power were preventing it. Theodore and M.S. had a long walk on shore. At noon, we pulled up for an hour or two, to give the men a rest, and after luncheon started for Esneh, which had been in sight all the morning. About 5 o'clock we were slowly stealing by the town, to our mooring place beyond. The more modern part of the town looking quite attractive with some good houses, and many trees, the older part rising from the river in very irregular fashion, the clustered mud houses looking more like a huge wasp's nest, than anything else - and just the same color. It is built over the mounds of the ancient city of Letopolis - the yawning apertures of which show that each innundation of the river, tumbles down a portion of it. As we sailed slowly along, we noticed a little tide of people from the town sitting in our wake, and by the time we pulled to shore on the banks of a flourishing green wheat field, we found a select audience squatted in a row in front of us, with new comers constantly arriving - some carried in their arms, turkeys and chickens, one brought a sheep, others, the pretty baskets made at Assouan and all the country about here - of which the fashion in shape and decoration has not changed since the days of the Pharaohs. One little black tot, about five years old, with remnants of a faded blue cotton gown hanging about his naked body, clutched so affectionately to him a sad, scrawney half-grown chicken, and every time I looked at him, he held up the poor thing by its wings, and grinned so anxiously at me, that I sent M.S. out with a half piaster to give him, and to tell him
to take himself and his chicken home. This treatment was so effective that the next morning early, he was found squatting on the same spot, and hugging the same chicken, prepared to repeat his experience of the night before. Esneh is noted for its colony of Chewagi Ghawazi , or dancing girls - and many of them came trooping down to the boat as soon as we arrived. The poor things looked so horrid in their wretched finery and bedizennings. One of them a tall, thin, fine looking woman, with large eyes and pleasant face, came lightly down the path, with a graceful free carriage which reminded me not a little of Ellen Terry, holding up her gaudy cotton gown a little to display a pair of white ruffled drawers, closed about the ankle, which she evidently thought very much à la mode, and greeted me with her pleasant voice, and a graceful bend of the head with, "good night, lady" - and turning to an Egyptian woman holding a baby, patted its cheek with affectionate gaiety, quite pretty to see. They are all disreputable women - and formed a great contrast to the other women, who, however ragged and dirty, always hold a part of their dress across the face, below the eyes. The sailors immediately began getting the boat in proper order for we are to lie here all day tomorrow, to give the sailors an opportunity for baking their new supply of bread - and for the first time the upper deck is enclosed with awnings, forming a charming appartment, which in the evening, lighted by our fine lantern, looked very pretty and festive. Everything at this hour is unusually quiet, most of the men having gone off - and their usual noisy drumming and singing is gratefully missed.

I have just come down from the upper deck, where we have been sitting and walking, since dinner. It was cheerful and homelike to look down on the lower deck, lighted with its lantern, and enclosed with awnings. M.S., Rais Achmed, Cook Hanna, Hassan, and a gen d"armes from the town who had come in for a visit, were all squatting about in a social circle, with pipes and coffee and gossip, while the little deck cook Benis, in his blue gown and white turban, hovered about them attending to their wants, being too young I suppose to be trusted to the gayeties of the town, to which all the sailors have cleared out. In the foreground stood our "house maid" Mahmoud, ironing clothes at a table - for we have had a great wash today - and I looked out on a very domestic scene from the cabin this morning. Just at the edge of the wheat, some of our poles were stuck in the ground, the ropes were stretched between, and such an amount of fluttering and drying linen. Two of the men were squatted on the ground, with two shallow tin tubs, like sponging tubs, and were washing. Our clothes seemed to awaken much interest, as I saw several of the men examining the strange garments - Theodore's pajamas, with their gay stripes seemed especially attractive. A small boy was hired to watch them and protect them from the too curious touch of any outside the "family", and to look after our live stock, which had been turned out for a day afield. Four turkeys were picketed near the coop containing the pigeons and chickens and an unsuspecting young sheep nibbled at the green wheat, as if he
expected an eternity of such pleasant days. Soon after breakfast we got into the felucca, and were rowed down to the town, where a donkey was pressed into my service, and we went through the town and bazaar, the rest walking beside and around me. The town and the bazaar was as filthy and discouraging as those we have seen in every other mud town of Egypt. The heat was great, and the flies thick. Then we went to the temple, which is more than half buried in the accumulated soil of centuries. Mohemet Ali cleared out the hypostyle hall, for some kind of magazine - the rest of it lies buried under the modern village. It belongs to the Roman period - is built of sandstone, and even to my uneducated eye, showed poor and rough sculpture, the capitals however were varied and graceful in design, and delicate in execution.

The afternoon and evening were very warm. We sat in our upstairs drawing room, the awnings raised on one side, and I never saw such stillness and repose as in the view we had before us. The river at Esneh is broad, and the low sand shores of the opposite side, with their fringe of palm trees against the yellow cliffs beyond them, the unruffled water, all were the expression of perfect repose. During the evening the Ramesis passed us, on her return trip.

A warm morning, made for the first time our little stove unnecessary. We were off with a good wind early, and made a fine run to Edfoo, 32 miles from Esneh, which we passed at four o'clock in the
afternoon. We could plainly see the lofty pylons of the temple, which we are to visit on our downward journey - and, having made over 40 miles, brought up at dusk under a superb grove of palm trees, too late for a walk on shore, though T. and M.S. tried it, coming back in a few minutes, reporting it very rough and dirty.

We are now lying under some lofty palms, the wind driving against us, and the ruffled water rolling us from side to side. We have been sailing like a steam boat all day and have made a splendid run. It was very exciting watching our boat racing along, throwing the water from her sharp prow - the big sail so often shifted - and the men skipping about like cats. The captain and sailors are so proud of the record we have made that they put forward every effort and our sailing today has reflected great credit on Rais Achmed. Within two or three days we have entered the sandstone country. The steep yellow unbroken cliffs which follow the eastern bank of the river for hundreds of miles, have given way to broken irregular sandstone hills, and today the shores begin to show rocks. The river too has narrowed and the current is stronger, the valley of the Nile too, is narrower, and the desert, often on both sides, has come down quite close to the river - making miles of desolate, but interesting scenery, the occasional little strip of cultivated land, showing emerald green in the desolation. We passed Gebel Silsileh, and then Kom Ombos like
the wind - and could only have a glimpse of them as we rushed by. We have reached the region of the "Sakkieh" or water wheel, which has almost superceded the pole and bucket of the Shadoof. The Sakkieh consists of two cogged wooden wheels, one set horizontally a few feet from the ground on the top of the river bank, which turns the second wheel placed vertically, with projecting beams, which support a chain of earthen jars - the main wheel is turned by oxen, and it is not only a labour saving machine, but a very picturesque one. It has its own music too, which is only a shade less melancholy than the song of the poor shadoof worker, because it is not the expression of a human voice. At a distance it sometimes reminds one of the bagpipe, and it possesses a unique gamut between creaking and groaning. We think we have made over 50 miles today!

A quick and delightful sail this morning from our resting place of last night, about 12 miles from Assouan, brought us to our landing place here at the Island of Elephantine, by 11 o'clock. M.S. audibly and devoutly thanked God several times, as he confessed he had much fear of our "big front sail" and now, this "big front sail" of which we have been so proud, is to be furled away before we leave Assouan for our downward journey - the towering boom alas! is to be lashed from end to end of the dahabeah, and the small aft sail and boom substituted - as with the downward current and the wind, the big
sail would make it dangerous. We drew up beside an English dahabeah, and immediately began preparations for a stay of several days. The men have been making ready for two or three days, washing their clothes, and getting themselves up in clean turbans, as most of them are Nubians, and live somewhere in the neighborhood of Assouan. Many of their friends have met them, and effusive greetings have been the order of the day. A cold and delicious wind was blowing and every breath was a pleasure. As you approach Assouan it presents so many startling and interesting features, that I cannot attempt a description now. As soon as we were fast, Theodore and Mary went for a little stroll along the sandy bank, and I amused myself vastly looking about. The men were springing about getting up their awnings the fowls were carried out and deposited on the sand, Benis' little cook stove too was picketed out - and M.S.'s magnificent tent was pitched, carpets and a table and chairs carried out to it, causing the wildest excitement to the group of half clothed juveniles who had gathered about us, - basket dealers and antiquity vendors arrived, and such greetings as "how d'ye do, baksheesh," "goodbye baksheesh" or "antiche, antiche" resounded. Presently arrived two slim young men, one of them a negro in a fez, wearing very awkwardly the European costume, who proved to be the agent of the American Consular Agent, who is himself, at Luxor - the other was his friend and interpreter, who had learned his really good English at the American School at Luxor, and when I asked him if it was usually as cold here, as this morning,
said "Oh! No! this was one single cold morning and he had taken some cough from it." Theodore got back in time to see these dignified officials, and Mary was in raptures at the "bazaar" which had accumulated itself on the shore.

In the afternoon Mary had a bad headache - and, leaving her under Georgette's care, Theodore and I took the felucca for a row amongst the islands - the men singing and pulling. The rock scenery in the neighborhood of the cataract is something very wonderful. Huge strange masses of granite broken, and heaped together in wildest confusion - hardly a sharp edge or angle anywhere - all worn and rounded by attrition, and the motion of water through enormous ages. Where the river has come in contact with the rock, it has covered it with a deposit of iron - and the strange forms into which it is worn, scooped out into giant cauldrons, and mighty sockets, give them the look of iron castings. These ancient stones covered in many places with the hieroglyphs of thousands of years ago, give one a glimmering perception of the age of one old world. The islands were so lovely with their groups of palms, and graceful scent and acacia trees - and their terraced low shores, formed by the receding waters of the river, gave them all a certain artificial air. We stopped at the small island of Shellal - and Theodore and M.S. climbed to a height, where a good view of the cataract was to be had. This, I was not up to, so I walked about as well as I could through the sand, and over the stones, guarded and followed and supported by two of our men. Part of the island was
carefully irrigated, and huma, mimosa and acacias were thriftily growing. The men got me some branches of a shrub I had noticed here and there along the shores, with delicate, rather stiff green branches thrusting themselves out in the slanting graceful fashion a buck tree has. The leaf was like a mimosa, small and insignificant, with strong sharp white thorns, two or three times as long as the primate leaf, in the axis of which they grew. We met a little old Nubian woman, almost clean, stepping briskly along. She had nice eyes and a pleasant voice, and asked no baksheesh. She was much pleased when M.S. addressed her in Nubian, and said he belonged to her country, looking shyly up at the tall, dignified figure, and the handsome costume. She and I exchanged smiles now and then in the place of words, and when her way parted from ours, she gave us such cheerful goodnight greetings, that I think the memory of her will always abide with me. Soon after we encountered a good natured savage, with a spear in his hand, and a few insignificant rags hanging about his bronze body - he careered about us in warlike fashion, shivering his spear and pitching it at incredible distances - he did not demand baksheesh, but he clearly wanted to sell his spear. A half piastre which I gave him, transformed him into a peaceful, humble admirer, who went with me to the boat, and presented me at parting a bunch of fragrant lupine flowers, smiling and nodding at me, as long as he could see me. All these little things make such pretty and pleasant pictures to hang in the gallery of ones memory! That evening hour - the sweet note of some unknown bird - the strange scenery - the
two almost barbarous people, human beings like myself, with whom for a moment, I had come in friendly contact! Such memories become mental possessions! Then we rowed across the river to Assouan, and walked to the Post Office.

We are lying at the island of Elephantine (West side) opposite Assouan. Elephantine is in Nubia, Assouan on the border line of Egypt - the dahabeahs all moor at this island - and it forms almost the only verdantly green spot, in the barren desolation of the neighborhood of Assouan. It is crowded with palms and graceful acacias, and green with castor oil bushes, crops of wheat, lupins and the fragrant lentiles now in flower. Occasionally a splendid old sycamore, the true Plantanum Occidentalis is growing - between us and the town stretches a wide beach of loose sand - and the large town beyond is entirely Nubian in its inhabitants and features. All day long, the women are coming and going with their water jars, poised so gracefully on the head, or driving their ugly buffalo cows down to water - and the children haunt the dahabeahs, on the lookout for baksheesh, or offering some trifle for sale. Opposite, on its high bank, lies Assouan with its palm trees, its curious little R.R. station, its shops, bazaars, Cook's offices, government offices, etc. Along the principal street fronting the river, are some really good houses - the town is well built and moderately clean, and the English officers on their
horses, and Soudanese soldiers with their good uniforms and military bearing, give one a certain assurance of order and well being.
