The shore is lined with boats discharging and receiving cargoes, and one of the Egyptians police steam boats, or one of Cook's postal or passenger steamers, is generally lying there. The sands are noisy with the donkey boys and their donkeys - with grumbling camels and shouting drivers, with vendors of straw mats and baskets, and strange barbarous looking weapons, altogether making as we went over this morning, a most animated and interesting scene. A large garrison of Egyptian soldiers, mostly Soudanese, is stationed here - the officers are English. It has suffered much from the loss of its Soudanese trade, since the abandonment of the Soudan. It occupies the site of the ancient Syene, and boasted of temples, and a Nilometer, magnificent quays, of which some ruins are to be seen, and, considering its ancient glory, the prophecies of Ezekiel read most strangely. We walked along the pleasant highway shaded by palms, running along the bank of the river, until we reached the entrance to the bazaar, where is a little square with police station, dispensary, two or three sentinels, piles of cannon balls, and two cannons. The bazaar is in a way the most fascinating I have ever seen - with its pretty basket work, and the strange barbaric arms and weapons and ornaments - these are not so strange and interesting as the people - I feel as if I should never tire of going there, and seeing that motley crowd: Turks, Copts,
Greeks, negroes - splendid looking Ababdehs with their fine bearing; and delicate aquiline features, and voluminous white turbans - jet black Soudanese, with their heavy features - the women in their white clothes, with their black, black faces, with barbaric silver bracelets and anklets, rings in their noses and ears, and ornaments on the forehead - and above all, the wild looking Bushareen, with the hair in long thick curls - all made such a scene, that I could hardly give my attention to the fascinations of the bazaar. Theodore bought a really fine sword, and two assaigais, a Soudanese shield and other things - and Mary and I, some baskets and engraved gourds. We lunched early, and Theodore and M.S. rode over to Philae, Theodore well mounted on a horse that belonged a few weeks ago, to an English officer, killed in a skirmish with the Dervishes. After receiving a visit from Miss Harrison and Miss Clarke from the English dahabeah, Mary and I and Georgette went for a tour of the island in the felucca. One of the most fascinating features of dahabeah life is this little felucca - each one carries the national flag of the owner for the time of the dahabeah - and the sailors vie with each other in their songs. Our crack singer wins not only admiring attention, but bursts of applause and encores. These songs of the sailors interest me. At first, each one seemed like the other - all wild chants in minor keys - then one emerged in identity - then another - now, we all have our favorites - and the men are much pleased when we ask for them - "Aunt Emma's song" Mary calls one of them - because I one evening, wondering what the sentiment of
the song was, asked M.S. the meaning of the words - he replied with impressive and gently dignity, with his hand on his heart, "Madame, it is the song of the heart - the lie - and the world"! A very suggestive title! At another time when I asked him the meaning of a song, he said, "do not ask me Madame, it is not a good song". One especially pretty song, has a more marked cadence than any I have heard, and they sing it only when rowing - certain words coming in like a refrain all through it sound like, "Gwady mesh". M.S. told me this meant, "the flowery, shining way of the river"! No one knows how old this song may be, for this river to the Egyptians and Nubians has been for thousands and thousands of years "the shining way". On our return we found the cards of some English officers on our tea table, and an American dahabeah had arrived. We now make four here - as the "Flying Dutchman" came up this morning. M.S. tells me she has worked up the river in a very hard fashion, sailing night and day.

As we have been waiting for two days to go to Philae, Mary not being well enough, and hearing that the people from the two Cook steamers that came in yesterday, are going over tomorrow, we thought we might have it quite to ourselves today, and therefore last night ordered lunch to be prepared early this morning, and Theodore's horse and our donkeys sent over to ride back, for we took the train over,
fearing the ride both ways would be too much for me. We breakfasted early and went across to the R.R. station. This little railway running across the desert to a point above the 1st cataract, was built by the English, and is now owned by the Egyptian government, and was used through the war for transportation of stores and troops. Such a comical little affair - the engines painted white, the single passenger car a broad long box, with divans on each side running the length of it, covered with flowered calico! It brought us in half an hour to the station opposite Philae, and we were taken across in a native boat to the lovely island. Familiar as I was with its general features from prints and photographs, it looked as strange in its wild chaotic setting of fantastic rocks. No words can give any idea of the remarkable rock scenery of the first cataract. We climbed the steep bank, and took our way over the debris of ruins to the lovely little temple known as "Pharaoh's Bed" with its group of overhanging palms. Here we sat down in the bright sunlight, and tried to think we were quite comfortable, for the morning was cold, on the terrace in front of the temple, looking sheer down to the river. We soon had some hot coffee served, thanks to the thoughtfulness of M.S. Theodore lighted a cigar, Mary went off some distance to sketch this little temple, and I opened my books to read about its history. Across the river at the edge of a town was a burying ground and little mosque - and a strange sound of wailing attracted my attention. I saw a great collection of people, and with the glass discovered that a funeral was taking place - and these dole-
ful sounds came from the women mourners, who in a body apart from the rest, were going through the customary perfunctory mourning, throwing the head violently backwards and forwards, their long hair streaming in the wind - a custom old as the hills about us. Then we were visited by a Mr. and Mrs. Newman - he, a Florentine Artist, American by birth, she, an Englishwoman. They are living in their dahabeah, lying just below us - having received permission from government to take their dahabeah above the first cataract (which has not been allowed since the war) as he is making some colored drawings of the temple. We walked about with them for awhile, and found them very agreeable, and not offensively instructive - she with that air I always envy in English women - of serene satisfaction in her own being, opinions and conditions. We went with them through the first great court, with its splendid colonnade on either side - but of unequal length, and set at irregular angles - the center of it heaped with the mud brick ruins of some Coptic houses, now destroyed, which also had invaded the lovely little temple at the corner of the largest colonnade, just hanging over the river in its ruins. Even the space between the seven Hathor columns had been built up with mud bricks. At the further end of this court is the well known great portal, flanked by its mighty pylons, with their huge sculpturings - beyond this, an inner court with colonnades on either side, with rooms and chapel opening off from one of them. Here, the capitals of the columns were beautiful - then followed the second pylons, and pillared portico, with its profuse sculptures
and hieroglyphs - every where it has been brilliantly painted - and the well known capitals are still brilliant with color - such lovely greenish blue, the predominating color - pure as the sky - such delicate red pinks and tender greens - it must be the despair of any artist to attempt in fresh color, to represent these tints worn by time to such soft brilliancy. This painted portico was quite filled with the workmen and their ladders, of some Frenchman engaged in the atrocious process known as "squeezing" - which consists of a moist preparation of paper applied to the surface - a process which takes away all colour from the sculpture - and everywhere we have been in Egypt, traces of this nefarious process can be seen. Into the dark gloomy rooms beyond this portico we went, and tried to make out some of the sculptures, then up the staircase to the roof of one of the pylons to see the curious little temple of Osiris - a kind of Holy of holies - representing the death process of mummification, and bringing to life of Osiris. By this time, the wind had increased to such violence, that nothing could be seen because of the clouds of blinding dust - and we were glad to take shelter in the so called "Queens Chamber", opening out of the inner court, where in the gloom and dust, M.S. and "Jagoub" were busy setting out our lunch - and what a good one it was! The wind increasing, we sent a card to Mrs. Newman, excusing ourselves from tea, and were taken across the river again, and after some noisy talking and vociferating, were riding home across the desert - the wind almost tearing our clothes off of us - and sending cataracts of sand into our
eyes and ears - We were happy to reach the comfort and seclusion of our little home - and the steaming samovar, and refreshing tea. M.S. went across to the P.O. for us, and brought back an armful of papers and letters.

We took things rather quietly this morning, and not until after eleven o'clock did we get into the felucca for a row around the island of Elephantine - and to the strange music of the sailors' songs, we glide past the shining hieroglyphed rocks, the little beaches with their different levels, looking like shallow flights of steps - the green shores - the groups of waving palms, and pull up at the foot of the steep cliffs on the western side of the river. These cliffs are thickly and softly carpeted with yellow sand - and up this we begin climbing, to visit the tombs opened by General Grenfell two or three years - but this was very hard work - and two of the men making a kind of chair with their arms and hands, carried me to the platform, 100 feet high upon which these tombs open. They belong to the 6th and 12th dynasties - the most perfect one is that of an officer of King Pepi 2d. The paintings are something startling and wonderful in their freshness - with a brilliant white metallic background, and the colors as fast as though laid on yesterday. So new and fresh did they look that Theodore scouted politely at my assertion that they had not
been "restored". Coming away we saw what I might call a hillside of human skulls and bones, and fluttering shreds of mummy cloth - and the Custodian of the tombs had a sweetly pretty collection of grinning skulls, and stray femurs and tibias etc. mingled with a few insignificant ornaments and rude broken pottery. Am so sorry I did not buy one of these ancient skulls for Will Rogers! It never occurred to me like most of my happy thoughts until too late. After luncheon again in the felucca and across the river, and while Mary and Theodore walked, I went into the bazaar with M.S. and some of our men. We then mounted horse and donkeys and went out to some ancient granite quarries, passing through an Arab cemetery, than which, amidst such a scene of desolation as that, nothing more dismal can be imagined. In this quarry there lies a giant obelisk in the rough - with no inscription to tell for whom it was intended, and ages ago, deserted and left unfinished. The manner of cutting these stones is very plainly to be seen, in the rocks about here - lines of wedge holes, into which wooden wedges were driven, and then soaked with water, caused the rock to split, along the line desired. We rode home through the town, by devious ways through narrow streets, and under arches - giving most picturesque effects, and our clattering cavalcade brought all the inhabitants to the front - then we came out upon the river bank, and found our felucca waiting - and were rowed home across a river, reflecting in most tender manner the delicious sunset colouring of sky and mountain.

We have had a whole delicious day at Philae! Scorning to take the R.R. train again I protested that I would ride both ways. An early breakfast, and a great stir of preparation among M.S. and the men, the saddles and the lunch baskets, the portable table and the camp chairs, and the rugs, all of which M.S. thinks essential to our comfort, had been sent over before us - and then the men pulled us over and there were our animals saddled and bridled - one sumpter mule or donkey almost hidden under his load. M.S. rode - but 3 of our men who went with us, walked or ran all that distance. The morning was lovely, and I felt at peace (with one or two exceptions!) with all the world as we took our way across the railway, then through some narrow streets, and up the barren hill side - through the cemetery, and out upon the desert. The road, or rather wide track through the sand, is really an ancient highway, between the cataract and Assouan - as the inscriptions upon many of the rocks on either side testify - some of these consist merely of names - others are a kind of votive tablet, inscribing thanks and praises to the gods of the cataract - kings, priest and generals have left here on these rocks records of their journey from the Soudan. The rocks are most fantastic - piled up on their enormous rounded surfaces - in many places showing the sky between their interstices, and looking as if a breath of wind might topple them over - and everywhere the yellow, yellow sand from the Lybian desert - in some places in such great drifts between the hills,
that they looked like glazier beds of solid gold. Where the rocks had been broken, the syenite or porphyry showed most lovely tints. I could not but exclaim again and again at the beauty of the rose and pink tints - and the rock showed here and there under our feet, through the yellow sand, like a rosy substructure. The ride of 6 miles seems very soon to come to an end, although in the defiles of the hills the sun burned out of the deep blue cloudless sky down upon that yellow sand, in a way that made us wonder how human beings could make that transit in summer. We found a native boat waiting for us, and we were rowed some distance, then got out and climbed a hill to see the cataract - and some half dozen, naked shivering men swim down it. The best exploit was that of a Nubian who went down on a leg through the midst of it, waving a red flag, without once losing his seat. I thought he well deserved the two piastres he got for this performance. In the distance we could see a dahabeah belonging to the English general commanding the frontier, making the ascent, and the swarms of natives on the rocks. Then we were rowed back to Philae and were happy to see a large party of Gage's tourists just leaving it. Our little "Dragoman" was waiting at the top of the bank, and was my bewitching and devoted slave all day, waving his little fly brush about me, and screaming "imshee" "imshee" to every other child who approached me. I hardly know what it was in that child that was so touching and attractive, that little brown figure so pretentious in its affectation of help, the patient little sober face, rarely lighting into a sunny smile
- the waiting watchful little eyes, absorbed in me and my comfort went straight to my heart - and I cannot think of him without a little stab of pain in my heart - and when we said goodbye to him as we came along in the afternoon, he followed us to the boat crying "goodbye- goodbye".

We lunched in Pharaoh's Bed", which I grieve to say was large enough to accommodate three other dahabeah parties - and then while Mary was sketching, Theodore and I wandered about the whole of the island, and sat down in the little temple of Nectanebo, with its Hathor headed columns, at the corner of the west colonnade of the large court - and looked down upon the river and off to the mountains over which that beautiful warm pinkish tinge which we have so often noticed on the Nile, was already gathering. We might have thought of the old Ptolemies, of Cleopatra, of the changing fortunes and history of this lovely island, but, as Mariette says, "the impression of the moment must prevail over the memories evoked", and we drank in the beauty without saying much of its history - while trying to photograph the scene upon my mind, the thought arose again and again "Will I ever see this again"! I made afterwards a very faithful tour of the island climbing over big rocks, and stumbling over small ones. There is a certain satisfaction in finding that the foolish craze for scribbling an unknown name on an undying monument, does not belong only to we moderns, for the walls, and pylons and columns of this temple show that for ages this has been done by those visiting the island. But all the same, "James B. Seranton" cut deeply into the stone followed
by the names of an American town and state, looks more intrusive and intolerable than one done in Greek or Latin. We rowed partly around the island before we said a final adieu, and the effect was most lovely, looking up to the stately temples - the groups of graceful palms and mimosas hiding much of the debris at their base. The ride home through the desert, was even more lovely than in the morning - the soft sunset lights were so beautiful in all that desolation. We heard the sweet warbling of the crested lark about us - and dozens of the pretty things were flying about the rocks - and numbers of strange little birds with brown and gray plumage and red bills were so tame they would hardly move out of the path before us. Home across the river at last, tired and sleepy - a warm welcome from all the men, Rais Achmed waiting to receive us - and Hassan's dinner table ready and inviting.

This afternoon the felucca took us across to Assouan, to visit the Government Dispensary, as we wanted glue, sticking plaster, and quinine pills - only this last could be had. T. and Mary then walked, while M.S. and some of the men went with me in to the bazaar, where I never tire of going, and looking at that strange crowd. The Busharin Bedouins are the most barbarous looking men you see - and such splendid looking fellows from Khartoum, with their fine bearing - and their regular features - and their bronze skins. They look as if they
might all be Ben Hurs - and Abdallahs! I came away with some very pretty Nubian baskets - and was rowed down to the trysting place. I saw Sir Frederick and Lady Hughes entering the Cook's steamer "Amasis" so I was carried ashore, and walked down to it meeting Mary and Theodore on the way, and we all went on board to look them up - found them and asked them to dinner, promising to send the felucca for them. They accepted with delight evidently - as Lady Hughes was very anxious to know something of life of a dahabeah. Then we hurried home through the rose tinted water, to give the cook a warming. Such dismay as it created, for he declared he had nothing! absolutely nothing, with his hand upon his heart in a tragic manner. Then I attempted to subdue some of the eastern abundance of the table, and plunged Hassan in deep despair by telling him to carry three of the four dishes of nuts he always will put on the table away - and making a selection from the numerous sweetmeats, and keeping only one dish of oranges. Even M.S. thought I carried the matter too far, in my attempt at elegant simplicity. We had a delicious dinner, among other things a very knowing sweetbread vol-au-vent - and Hanna Ibrahim makes the most perfect pastry I have ever seen. This evidently commended itself warmly to Sir Frederick - and he was loud in his praises of our cook. We went up to the deck with Sir. F. and Theodore when they went to smoke. M.S. had arranged it most charmingly with lanterns, and the crew down on their deck played and sang their choicest songs. We sent them home delighted with their visit and could hear the songs of the men as they went in the stillness of the night across to the steamer.

Every day adds to the charm of Assouan - and we loudly and constantly bemoan the fact that we have so little time. We have discussed again and again the voyage to the 2d cataract but Cook's little postal steamers are filled with his own tourists, and there is no way to do it, but by chartering one of them, leaving the "Nubia" here to wait for us. It would be very expensive, and take about 3 more weeks, so we have reluctantly abandoned the scheme. We don"t yet allow Theodore to mention the leaving of Assouan, but I can see that the necessity of an early decision is growing more and more apparent. All of our men being Nubians they have been allowed to go to their homes for a visit, most of them taking a day or two or three - and every day now, Rais Achmed suggests through M.S. the propriety of settling upon a day of departure.

On our getting out of our felucca this morning at Assouan we were met by the youthful and comical agent of the Consular Agent at Luxor, who in his boyish timid manner begged M.S. to ask us to come to the Consulate and have coffee with him. We had seem him hovering on our skirts on several occasions, and knew this thing was imminent, so we assented with the best possible grace we could assume, and Theodore kindly turned him over to me to entertain, so I walked along with him and M.S. keeping up a certain amount of talk - while Theodore and Mary walked behind indulging in the most amusing criticisms of me and my
: official, but the little black fellow, looking so uncomfortable and gene in his European dress, seemed to find so much satisfaction in the situation, that all my impatience vanished. We went into a very good apartment, with flowered chintz divans, and tawdry Turkish decorations, and ornamented with several American flags - and had some poor coffee, Theodore said the cigarettes were worse - then got away, after a fraternal hand shake all around.

In the afternoon the wind being cold and strong I stayed at home - Theodore and Mary going in the felucca to some of the islands. I had a most deliciously quiet afternoon with my book on deck, protected from the wind by the close awnings, only opened just enough towards the west , to give me a view of the color deepening on earth and in the sky. Every night there comes a strange and very beautiful effect. The sun sets in a perfectly cloudless yellow sky - after he has gone down, a tender pink begins to blush deeply over the sky, turning to an amethyst blue at the horizon - the water reflects it, and the distant mountains are softly purple - and tonight the little silver thread of the crescent moon added to the lovely beauty of the evening. Just after Theodore and Mary got home, and we were taking tea about our smoking samovar, we had a pleasant visit from two English officers, who invited us to afternoon tea tomorrow, to see the Soudanese soldiers perform their national or tribal dances, which they always do on Friday, that being their Sunday.

A serious consultation was held this morning, as the question of the day of our departure could no longer be deferred. After sighs and groans and useless protestations, we finally decided that we must be off tomorrow. Mary at once said she should devote the morning to the painting of Mahomet Ali, our 2d steersman, so leaving her surrounded by her paints in the cabin with poor Mahomet stiffening out of all his usual grace, Theodore and I with four of the men went out in the felucca for a last tour among the islands. Theodore steering - to the great amusement of the men, who kept a furtive watch of him all the time - and when they had warned him to keep out from shore, and he had persisted in going his own way, and brought us scraping across a rock, after the first flurry of excitement, their delight was great - again and again they would be seized with fits of laughter, and not doubt they made a pretty story of it among themselves. How lovely it all was! As we came around the northern end of Elephantine, past the pretty little hospital with its green jalousies and awnings, we were passed by a large dahabeah carrying the English flag, and away down the river could be seen the white wings of another. Already, we number 10 at the mooring ground - and lie too close for comfort and health. We landed at Assouan and walked about, going once more and for the last time through the bazaar. At four o'clock in the afternoon the felucca took us across below the town, to the camp, and there at the landing we found Captain Judge,
and an Italian officer, Count Fabarella. We were first taken to the quarters of Capt. Judge, and had tea and some excellent hot toast, and saw some very interesting Dervish things - weapons, drums, saddles and their very extraordinary dress - looking as if it had been made out of a cotton crazy bed-quilt - the cap and the long gown being made of coloured cottons, very thickly wadded and quilted - it is said to form an excellent coat of mail. Then we walked about the quarters which were very neat - the mud houses of the officers painted white with protecting roofs - and neat little gardens, shaded by palm trees. The most interesting thing was the village where the wives and families of the soldiers live - the only clean mud town I have seen in Egypt. Some of the women were sitting at the doors of their little huts sewing. The children looked clean and had good eyes - and the women were good looking, quiet and respectful - their densely black skins, with their white dress and silver ornaments being very effective. There is a head woman or matron, Capt. Judge told us, who exercises a kind of discipline over the women - as to their cleanliness, order etc. and the pay of the men is so good, that many of them keep a servant. He also told us that there are now no English soldiers above Cairo - though all the principal officers are English. The Egyptian Army numbers about 13,000. All of the officers speak most highly of these Soudanese soldiers - even affectionately - they are tall, well made men - black as a polished stove pipe - quiet under discipline - of great endurance, and can outmarch any English or European soldier. They
receive 20 cents a day, clothes and rations - and are so much better off than in their native state, that the army can never want soldiers. They enlist during the pleasure of the Government, which really means for life, or as long as they remain able bodied. The utmost decency - cleanliness and order are exacted from them - and the army in this way, must act, through the influence of the English officers commanding it, as a potent engine for civilization and good.

By the time we had inspected the quarters, the dancers were in full swing - and we walked about looking at them. Every tribe danced by themselves - and two or three drummers formed the centre of each ring of dancers. Their drums were native, a rude kind of barrel, with a skin stretched on top, and drummed with the hand, in a particularly telling and exciting way. The dance began with a slow shuffling awkward circling about the drummers - each man held some stick or weapon, and as they warmed to the work, each seemed to do what he pleased in the way of drumming and shouting. I can imagine that in the native dress, or rather ornaments, it might be weird and horrible, but it seemed a trifle civilized and perfunctory - though we were told they keep it up for hours every Friday, with great enjoyment, and long after I was in bed, the distant sound of their drumming came to my ears. The officers walked down to our boat with us and siad goodbye, we came home in the twilight, the oars dipping into the calm pink water, and keeping time to the wild, low chanting of the men - the young moon trembling in the soft sky, and throwing a silver trail across the river,
in the distance the mountains glowing in deep warm purple - all the peculiar charming effect of an Egyptian evening, after the sun has just gone down. As we drew up to the Nubia, we groaned and sighed that this should be our last evening at Assouan.

At half past eight o'clock this morning as I was hurrying with my dressing, I heard the anchor pulled up, a babel of voices outside and Theodore calling us to hurry out and witness our departure. Two more dahabeahs arrived last evening, and as I went on deck, I felt the first shiver of movement, and one of these dahabeahs pulled up behind us to take our place as we moved away. Days ago, our big boom and sail in which we have taken such pride, was taken down and lashed along the length of the the dahabeah, and the small after sail put in its place. The planks were taken up in sections on the lower deck, so giving the 5 sailors on each side a place to sit and row - there they were, the oars in their hands, the ropes were hauled, and we pulled out into the current, and began our slow progress down the river. How sorry we felt to leave it all behind! and it seemed as if the day before us would be interminable. One after another of the pleasant land marks were left behind, and then a bend of the river shut it all away from our lingering eyes. There has been a light head wind all day - and against this our men rowed from the time of starting, until 12 o'clock, when they rested two hours - then took to
the oars again until half past six, bringing us about 12 miles from Assouan. Our sympathies have been excited for them, for the effort seems a great one. They stand on the narrow section of the deck, between the open divisions, giving in unison a strong pull backwards, then step down to a level below the section, giving another strong pull which brings them back upon their seats - the oars are suddenly raised, and the whole process begins again. During most of the time they sang. During all the time we have been on the river, we have had a south wind only for half or three quarters of an hour - and the prospect of rowing back to Cairo, seems a gloomy one today! The downward progress of a dahabeah on the river is a most absurd and humiliating one. Unless when rowed, or the unusual south wind fills the sail, the boat drifts, apparently helpless - and we have been amused and exasperated today to see the Nubia almost putting her nose into the mud bank on one side, then backing with her stern into the opposite shore, or going stern first down the river, or standing foolishly across it! and the points of the compass become hopelessly confused in your mind, and I am beginning to have some anxieties about Theodore, fear the inaction and slow progress may prove hard to bear. He ought to have another man with him. Going on deck after dinner we found every man almost of the crew already wrapped in their rugs, and asleep on the deck - I am sure we none of us slept as soundly as they did that night.

Much to our surprise and satisfaction this morning, we found a strong south east wind blowing, and Theodore came down from the deck to breakfast, saying we were sailing splendidly, and making six and seven miles an hour, and that Kom Omboa was in sight. We had intended stopping here on our way down, but really, except for real investigation, all that is left of the temple can be seen from the river. Built after the conquest of Alexander, the encroachments of the river are now fast destroying it - its façade has fallen, and huge stones lie half in and half out of the water. So it was decided not to interrupt our glorious course at that time, so flying past it we kept on our way. The wind increased in force, and by afternoon it was almost a gale, and the numerous rocks in the river made the sailing exciting. I was in my room, half asleep when I heard a great uproar on deck, the wildest shouting and jumping about. I hurried out of the cabin, but found the lower deck in such confusion I did not venture farther than the little gangway, but I saw that we were being driven by the wind on to the rocks and that the efforts of our excited Captain - steersmen and crew could not protect her from rather an alarming bump. Our first steersman however who is a dignified magnificent giant had left his rudder, cleared the lower deck with one bound, gone overboard, and took part of the shock from the Nubia, by offering his Herculean shoulder as a bumper. The whole action was really a splendid thing. At first, we did not know whether we were hurt or not - but examination revealed
no injury - and we thankfully pulled off the rocks and around a corner near two cangias or working boats, which had also blown ashore - and here we waited for the wind to lull. We got ashore and climbed the bank to see what we could see - and found ourselves in a wretched little encampment of Busharin - a man came to meet us with his long bushy curls stuck through with a wooden needle, and some green leaves - and the veriest yellow white rags I have ever seen gathered about his bronze body - his face was utterly out of keeping with all his surrounding, for it was a noble one, the features delicately cut, and the teeth perfect in form and pearly whiteness - his whole bearing was so noble and dignified that it was a little shock to see him put out his hand at once and demand backsheesh. There were two low tents covered with two or three miserable rugs and skins, not more than 4 feet from the ground. In front of the one before which we stopped, a young and rather pretty half clothed woman was squatting on the ground, with a pot sitting upon a little fire of sticks, into which, she was stirring water and flour. I think the only household utensils they had were that pot, the wooden spoon with which she stirred the soup, and a small gourd - a mangy dog hovered about - and as wretched a looking camel as I ever saw crouched near. She had a nice face, the same white glittering teeth, and a small irregular piece of silver coming out of one nostril, and flattened to the side of her nose - a safe way I suppose of carrying a valuable possession. A boy of about 5 years perfectly naked was standing by her and under the tent, lying in the dust which was here about a foot deep,
was a squalling brown baby of 2 years, who was presently scooped out of the dust, and crawling to his mother, squatted his little naked body by her side, tucked his head under her arm and fell to sucking as if he were a calf, and she a cow. Other men and naked children came up and join the party, and I thought what a scene it was - and what stages of civilization it showed. We, M.S. and some of our men with him, and this group of half starved savages! I gave the woman a silver half piastre - at which she laughed and seemed much surprised - turning it over and over with curiosity - and Theodore gave the man 2 piastres, which must have seemed a fortune to them. Jacoub was sent to the Nubia for Mary's camera. When the woman saw it, her face changed, and a look of fear came over it, and she began to mutter to herself as the camera was pointed to them. As we were walking on - the man pointing to a tent a short distance off, said to M.S. that we must not go there, as there was a man ill with small pox - so we gladly ended our expedition and came back to the Nubia. About 6, we got under way, and floated for three hours down near Silsileh, where we have anchored.

We dropped down early this morning to Gebel - Silsileh, where are the famous sandstone quarries of the ancient days. While sitting at breakfast, we were being made fast to the bank on the west side, consisting of a little strip of earth and sand, and the sand stone cliffs rising irregularly beyond. The river narrows very much here, and the
mountains come down on either side close to the water. There was a special worship of the Nile at Silsileh, and the rocks are covered with inscriptions - consisting of hymns addressed to the river - some of them Mariette says in "lefty strains". The custom too of the ancient Egyptians of having a stela, or speos, or inscription commemorating of a visit to any consecrated spot, is shown here as on the road from Assouan to Philae. Many of the numerous grottoes here were tombs. Among the commemorative grottoes, the richest and most highly decorated were those of Rameses 2d, Seti Ist and Memptah Ist - the façades supported by lotus columns - and must have been very beautiful in their prime - but the rich sculptures are mutilated and the paintings faded. Most of them consist of little corridors in the rock, with 3 or 4 openings - all have seats at the ends and the now mutilated figures sitting on them, as Miss Edwards says "like owners in their opera boxes" give a very strange effect. What a strange scene it must have been here at that time, the rocks on the western shore gay with paintings, and the silent stone figures sitting in their boxes watching it all. The climbing here was something fearful - and I did not suppose I would be able to see much of the grottoes and quarries, but Mahomet Ali and Jacoub and sometimes René carried me up and down and about that day, with the most smiling alacrity, wading through the sand and up and down the rocks the wind almost blowing my coat off me. The quarries on the eastern side are much more important and interesting - we crossed over in spite of the violent wind, and found them really
wonderful - great detached cubes and masses - their sharply cut edges rising straight up 50 and 60 ft. - avenues cut in the rock as clean as it had been done yesterday - everywhere the wedge shaped markings like those at Assouan. It makes one giddy to try and think of the toiling millions that must have labored here - their lives, and their time of no significance to the haughty kings, who commanded and it was done. All is open to the blue sky - Miss Edwards gives an excellent description of these quarries. When we crossed back to the Nubia, the wind was so violent, we shipped water, and had to make a long distance. In the afternoon we went to the important "grotto of Horus" the last king of the 18th dynasty. It is a long corridor out in the rock, and supported by four pillars - its rich sculptures and painting are mutilated and worn, until they are almost undecipherable - irregular holes 4 and 5 inches deep drilled into them, show how careful the destruction has been. The beautiful bas relief so well known of a goddess suckling the infant Horus is here. Mariette pronounces it the best specimen of Egyptian art - and in spite of the ruin of it, it shows a sweetness and sentiment I have seen nowhere else. At the other end of the grotto is the almost equally well known "Triumph of Horus". While Theodore and Mary went off with M.S. for what they called a walk, I and Georgette strolled up and down the little beach where we had landed in the felucca, and picked some leaves of all the different things we could find, - almost all of which M.S. pronounced "poison" when he saw them - though I knew better.

A favoring wind this morning, and the stout arms of our sailors brought us so far on our way today, that when after luncheon we went on deck, we were amazed to see the lofty pylons of Edfoo, towering in the distance. The day was enchanting - the water without a ripple - and reflecting the golden tint of the mountains on the eastern shore. Before 3 o'clock we had pulled up to the bank, where a flock of donkeys and donkey boys had sprung up by some sort of magic, and after the usual wrangling and shrieking whilst the choosing and saddling of the donkeys was going on, we were en route for Edfoo. Clattering through the narrow streets between the mud houses, past the little American Mission school, and the Arabian school, where all the little Arabs were squatting on the ground swaying and shrieking their Koran, which is the only thing taught them, we went at last through a narrow lane, and dismounted at the top of a long flight of rude stone steps down to the level of the entrance to the temple. This important temple was entirely excavated (through the liberality of Ismail, father of the present Khedive) by Mariette in 1864, it was before that time smothered in the natural accumulation of the soil, and covered and surrounded by the mud houses of the village. Even the courts and chambers were filled almost to the top with debris - now all is entirely cleared - and the great temple lies entire and almost perfect - even to its enclosing wall, between which and the immense mounds of rubbish cleared from it, and which rise outside
almost to the top of it in places, there is a kind of moat. Where this rubbish is cut through, it shows complete strata of broken potsherds. I shall certainly not attempt a description of this temple - it can be found in a dozen books. When we arrived at the iron gate which stretches across the portal, it was found that M.S. had forgotten the tickets, and while one of the men was despatched for them, we stood and gazed up at its great pylons, with their huge strange sculptured figures, which seemed to tower above us into the deep blue sky - when finally, the tickets arrived, the obdurate old custodian allowed us to enter the great hypostyle hall, where near the entrance there was a little table and chair, and O! shades of the Pharaohs! a visitors book, in which we were asked to put our names! This hall has an almost perfect colonnade on its four sides, then opens into the smaller court with its great columns, and then through the transept court, you gain the sanctuary beyond, where the monolithic granite shrine from some former temple, so often described, is standing in one corner. There are a series of rooms opening out from the smaller court, and running around the sanctuary - but the most wonderful feature of the temple is the lofty encircling wall, its entire surface covered with hieroglyphic inscriptions and sculptures. It is of Ptolemaic origin, and some idea of its dimensions may be gains by the statement of the fact that the pylons are only 32 ft. lower than the top of the Vendame column. We climbed the staircases, their walls crowded with figures, to the roof, where an enchanting view was opened to us. I shall not soon forget
one beautiful effect as we stood in the great court, near the smaller hypaethral one, through the opening of, which the intensely blue sky, against which an eagle was slowly flying, showed in contrast to the soft yellow cream of the sandstone! The scamper back to the Nubia would have been charming had it not been for the chattering donkey boys and men, and the universal demand for backsheesh from every native we saw. When we reached the dahabeah, we found the usual market being held on the bank - women with baskets of eggs - pigeons and chickens. The simplest purchase from the natives becomes apparently an exciting and dangerous affair - they scream - they gesticulate - they call frantically upon Allah, but once the purchase is made, they relapse into quietness. No wonder they try to get all they can from these rich Howadji - what must we seem to them with all our belongings! One handsome rascal with glittering eyes and whitest teeth had a veritable "antika" to sell, which Theodore at last bought - and archaic figure in alabaster - one of a triad evidently, as the feet of another one remains. The night is exquisitely beautiful - we have dropped down 6 miles from Edfoo, to a safer anchorage. We were walking the deck for some time - the moon shining safely bright - Orion stretched out above us - the Dipper standing on one end, having lost the last star of the handle - the water rippling against our bow, each ripple touched into silver - the only discordant sound the laboured rowing of the sailors.

We make such early starts now, in order to get as far as possible before the north wind gets up that sleeping after 5 o'clock is a difficult thing. Today we have had very little head wind, and since 12 o'clock the river has been like a soft blue mirror, reflecting the warm yellow of the sandstone cliffs of the east side, and on either shore every object has been reproduced, inverted. The men sang and pulled lustily, and we made very good progress, until 3, when a wind from the north spoils everything - and with Esneh in sight the whole afternoon we have only succeeded in coming to a stop for the night just below the Russian Consulate, at 7 o'clock. Again this evening repeats the same soft beauty of last - and we rejoice that we shall have the full moon during our stay at Luxor.

Light winds and the sturdy arms of our crew today, brought us from Esneh to Luxor, 36 miles. Passing Erment in the afternoon, M.S. wanted to stop and go ashore to a garden he knows well for fruit. Of course we went with him - I was glad to see the garden and Mary delighted to pick oranges and lemons for herself. I have never seen such magnificent lemons - and the oranges were very large and sweet, and we brought away two baskets filled with them. A young man about the garden spoke excellent English having learned at the school at Assiout. The oranges were ornamented with their own handsome leaves.
We got too, some huge stalks of Pampas grass - and some trailing branches of the Loofa - a cucurbitous plant, the fruit producing the fibrous sponges known so well in commerce. The dahabeah had floated down to the town by the time we left the garden, and we pulled out to her in the felucca, and from that time until we were called to dinner, we sat on the deck entranced with the wonderful beauty of the evening. The same strange beauty was again repeated in the sky, and reflected in the glassy water, the softest sweetest pink deepening into a turquoise blue - never was there such delicate, luminous, trembling color - it was as if sky, atmosphere and earth were made of liquid opals. The men were quieted by the beauty - and sand their songs softly - and some were at their devotions prostrate. We had not finished dinner before we arrived, and when we went on deck we found ourselves on fete - colored lights swung from the masts and hung about everywhere - and Cook Ibrahim was sending off rockets, which were received with shouts of admiration from the shadowy stretches of the river. We found the "Flying Dutchman" lying just behind us. M.S. went off directly with some of the men to the Post Office, and returned with a large parcel of letters and papers, which we have been busy reading all the evening.

It was cold this morning, so much so, that we sat for some time after breakfast reading Galignani. Then we went for a walk in the town, and wandered about the temple. We are lying against some
pleasant fields, a little distance beyond the Luxor Hotel. We found it warm enough walking - and when after lunch we mounted our donkeys for Karnak, the sun was tremendously hot. I thought we would shrink up in it, and Theodore seemed to feel quite ill. Who can describe Karnak, and indeed who would attempt it? We dismounted in the great court and took shelter for awhile in the cool shadows of the wonderful hypostyle hall - with its 129 giant columns. It is the largest hall ever built by the Egyptians, and is the work of that King of builders Seti 1st. We sat down on some of the great fallen blocks - and we looked and felt like pigmies. Then when we had grown a little too cold for it is always one or the other thing in this climate, we opened Mariette and read his description of the temple. I believe the giant monolith of red Assouan granite, which stands the taller of the two tall obelisks now left there, impressed me most - it is covered with inscriptions, exquisitely cut. The ride home was very hot, and we found our cool shaded deck, with its easy chairs, and the fragrant tea and coffee which were waiting for us, most comfortable. At 5 o'clock, the thermometer marked 78 in the shade! The evening was wonderful with its exquisite sunset and gorgeous with clouds and color.

It is just one week since we left our beloved Assouan! We decided last evening to go over to the temple of Medinet Abou early
this morning, and return in time for lunch - and so directly after breakfast we were pulled across the river, after much preparation in the way of veils, payments etc. for the day was hot, and the light intense. The river here is wide, and on the other shore, extremely shallow, so that even a row boat cannot approach it for a distance of from 75 to 100 feet - here the men got out into the water and took us ashore. I put my arms around their necks and was safely landed, and stood laughing at the rest as they were landed in this undignified manner, especially Theodore and M.S. who looked so absurd. We found our equipment of donkeys here, and our saddles, which had been sent across early, on them, and we took our way across the wide sands, then on to a high canal looking down on the green fields, then through an Arab village with its peculiar odour, always reminding us of a dish of curry, then pitching a tremendous incline down to the dry bed of one of the big irrigating canals, and sharply up its opposite bank, we rode along a grove of palms, and then struck into a little bridle path, leading through the pleasant rye and barley fields - though warm, it was most delightful with the great yellow mountains in front of us, with their pinkish shadows sleeping in the hollows - while - could it be true! the great Colossi of the plains defining themselves in the distance, and growing bigger and bigger! Every one must I think, have the same feeling on first beholding these giants. Are they only melancholy monuments of the glory of a past gigantic art - or do they wait expectantly oblivious of this
little present, and of our little selves! Their patient attitude seems to confirm this idea - and one is filled with awe when one gets a dim sense of how they have ben sitting there thousands of years! When a long distance from them, one invests their faces with expression but a nearer view shows them battered and broken - every feature gone. They were originally monoliths - but one of them has been restored with layers of sandstone. They are of breccia, and stood before a temple every vestige of which is gone, and both represent - Amenophis III. They stood 60 ft. high, though now the soil has accumulated more than 6 ft. about them - but they are colossal, as we pause under them and ride about them. A little distance on, you strike the desert line, and begin to take your way at the edge of the ancient necropolis - which here at least, must have yielded up all the dead ever committed to its keeping, so full is it of yawning pits and excavations. The reflection of the sun strikes burning hot from the yellow sand, and I am glad enough to take my parasol from the faithful Jacoub, who has been running all the time, with my donkey boy by the side of me, with M.S. hovering about on his donkey not and then to see if I was properly cared for. Medinet Abou would be almost as hard to describe as Karnak. It is the wonderful monument built by the brilliant Ramesses 3rd to celebrate his victories and achievements - and is preceeded by a small temple of Thotmes 3d or Hatasou - and by the palace or pavilion of Ramesses 3d - which some suppose to have been a royal residence, so unique is its arrangement, but which was more probably a fortress.
Here are shield shaped battlemented walls. The grand temple with greater and lesser court, the former with its Osiride piers on two sides, and great columns on the other, with their unusually deep hieroglyphs and sculptures, with very much of the brilliant blue colouring remaining, was fascinating. One could spend hours and days looking at and studying the sculptured walls, I climbed about as much as I could over the great debris, supported so effectually by M.S. and one of the men, that I thought my arms would be dislocated! Them we mounted again and rode through the old grove pits, and along the strip of desert land between the mountains and the cultivated plain to the temple of Goornah, built by Seti Ist to the memory of his father Ramesses Ist. Here the sculptures are most delicate and beautiful, and show the perfection of that culminating period of art. In one of the side chambers is a head of Seti Ist which is always pointed out, and which is really beautiful in its lines, but which alas! has lost all its colouring through that disgraceful process of 'squeezing". The ride home at high noon through that blazing sun was something rather uncomfortable. We found our little felucca, with its awning and stars and stripes waiting for us, and we were carried out to it, after the usual noisy settling up with guides and donkey men. How deliciously cool and secluded the cabin of the Nubia seemed to us! The thermometer in the shade of the deck awning marked 78 degrees. In the afternoon we looked at some antiquities in the town - feeling very shy of most of them - knowing that a thriving manufacture of them is driven in Luxor.

Orders had been issued last night for an early breakfast, and an immediate start for the Tombs of the Kings - and as I came out of my room this morning, I found M.S. striding in and out of the cabin in his riding dress, looking like a handsome brigand, and he made me laugh by saying "Moi, je voyage toujours come un canon"! A cool wind was blowing, but an intense sun shining, against whose too ardent rays we had protected ourselves with veils, parasols and puggarees and blue glasses. The same pleasant crossing in the felucca to the shallow shores beyond, across which we were borne to dry land by our men, as yesterday - then again across the wide stretch of yellow sand to the high embankment, and then the sharp turn at the mud village, filled with troops of little bare bronze children, and then the long ride through the rich barley fields - for the Theban crops are especially rich - we pass the Colossi, and turn to the right, and riding along the desert edge of this great necropolis, we took our way through and up the path of a mountain torrent which seemed a very valley of desolation - not a living thing - not the faintest trace of vegetable life, or a blade of grass - the sandstone cliffs towering above us on either side, and the sun blazing out upon us from the pitiless sky. What a blinding heat it was, and what a scene of chaotic desolateness! our donkeys picked their way along one after the other with a patient dejection - our men were breathless and perspiring, and I did not like to think of the three girls, almost children who carried the water Page 86: goolaks on their heads and who are always waiting on the bank of the river for tourists, and for a few piasters run along with the donkeys with these jugs on their heads - though far in the rear, they stepped along cheerfully over the sharp stones with their bare feet, and if you looked at one, she would immediately show every tooth she had in a broad smile. Occasionally we pulled up in the 'shadow of a great rock" for a moments rest - and I thought as I am continually doing in this country, how natural the Eastern imagery of the Bible seems! At last we came to a kind of cul de sac in the yellow rocks, where is the tomb of Ramesis 9th, and here we dismounted, for beside seeing the tomb we were going to lunch there. Our patient little donkeys were left in the blinding heat outside, while the men and guides huddled themselves together in the shade of the inclined entrance, while we took possession of the cool, gaily painted portal - our sumpter mule was unpacked, rugs laid down, camp stools and table spread, and an elaborate lunch ready. Our three little water carriers squatted near us - girls not over 9 or 10 years of age - pretty things they all were, with their beautiful eyes, white teeth and pleasant voices. One of them called Fatima so endeared herself to Mary, that she has promised to come to the dahabeah tomorrow, to be painted. After our lunch, we lingered and rested until four o'clock - afraid to venture out in the heat - and we walked down the descending corridor of the tomb examining the strange paintings. Then we went a short distance to the well known and often described tomb of Seti Ist commonly called "BelgonèBelzoni's Tomb", from the fact that
he opened it in 1817. He found that it had already been rifled, but that very little injury had been done to the paintings - which is more than can be said of it now - as savants and tourists share the odium of its present defaced state. It is the most remarkable thing - cut into the solid rock, 470 feet - along the gradual descent of the corridor we went the light from the entrance growing dimmer and dimmer, until we came to a steep broken staircase, the lower part of it lost in black darkness - then all our candles were lighted, and with Mahomed's help stumbled down it until we came to a room, then down another staircase and finally plunged into the yawning blackness of another - the candles flickering and trowing strange lights on the brilliant paintings and hieroglyphs which cover every part of the halls and chambers. Strange monsters and huge serpents writhe along the walls, and guard the entrances. The cheerful realistic representations of every day human life, which the tombs of the earliest dynasties show, are not here. In their place, evil demons and shapes represent the more modern ideas, of the struggle of the soul with evil - and on these walls the whole elaborate story of the judgement and trial of the soul after death is given - Anything more strangely impressive than these great chambers in the heart of the mountain, with their brilliant and elaborate decoration, cannon be imagined. And the thought of the amount and difficulty of the labour, was overpowering. What a commentary too, are these strange tombs, hid away in this wild and almost inaccessible valley, on the stability of human effort and ambition! To think of these right Page 88: royal old kings, supreme in their power and pride fashioning and decorating their tombs through life and securing as they imagined their regal bodies from desecration, their secret burial, the building up and concealment of the entrance after burial, and it is said, the killing of the priests and all who knew of its location - and, in some after time of danger and emergency, the careful gathering of all the bodies, and their transference to the deep well like tomb where they were found a few years since, and conveyed to the Boulak museum, and now lie open to the gaze of the tourist of the 19th century! It is thought now that the temples known as Medinet Abou, the Ramesseum, Temple of Goornah, Deir-el-Bahari etc., which stand along this great stretch of desert land, lying along the mountains here, separated by no great intervals, so that one can easily be seen from the other, are the Mastabas, or mortuary chapels of their kings, buried beyond and above them in the valley of the Bab-el-Moulak.

On coming out of the tomb of Seti 1st, we went to that of Ramesis 3d or Brun's Tomb as it is often called, or the Tomb of the Harpists, from the admirable paintings so well known of two men playing harps. The finish and execution of this tomb is far inferior to that of Seti Ist. Here as at Philae are numerous Greek "graffiti", showing that they were open to the inspection of travellers in the times of the Ptolemies. Our ride down the valley was much more pleasant in the cool of the afternoon, and we stopped at the Ramasseum and rode about it, seeing it very well in this way. The most gigantic
statues known, lies here fallen and broken. It is of granite and represents Ramasses 2d. Of all these temples or mortuary chapels, this one seems the most cheerful, standing as it does without any enclosing walls, and few encumbering Roman and Coptic ruins, which give such an air of squalid desolation, with their masses of crude crumbling bricks.

This morning being very warm, and we rather tired from the long expedition of yesterday, felt very little energy. Mary was to stay at home of course, and paint little Fatima, for whom the sailors went across the river while we were at breakfast - she arrived in due time, but what with her eyes all blackened, and many gew-gaw ornaments she did not look the pretty child she did yesterday. We left them under Georgette's care, and went off to the town antiquity hunting. M.S. had introduced us to an old Mohanmmed Mohassib - a friend of his, and the most prominent dealer in antiquities in Luxor. Theodore bought several good things of him this morning. In the afternoon Theodore and Mary declining all guides and attendants, rode off to Karnac, and home in time for dinner - while I lounged about the deck with my book, enjoying everything. We are moored to a high bank, along the top of which the usual road or path runs - and along this people are coming and going continually - tourists, and fellaheans - camels and donkeys. Just above us on the bank, M.S. has pitched his beautiful tent - and at different levels of the bank are our belongings in the way of chicken
coops - picketted turkeys and a lamb - Tommy's little cook stove - drying clothes etc. etc. This evening old Mahommed Mohassib appeared a really interesting old man, speaking English imperfectly but intelligibly - with such a gentle respectful manner. I am beginning to look upon him in the light of a friend. He was very mysterious at first, and I felt that something was in the air, and he presently explained that two very fine mummy cases and some papyrus had come into his possession that day, which had been taken out of a tomb only the day before, and if the governor would like to see them, he would send for them. A young son of his whom he is bringing up to the business was with him, and he was despatched for the things - and after awhile returned with a man, bringing in a huge, mystic looking black parcel, from which were taken the heads of two fine mummy cases, and a basket of papyrus, which seemed to have been hastily stripped from the mummy case, as particles of it were still adhering to the case. It was very much broken, Theodore after some haggling bought them all - and the heads were transferred to the top of the big locker in my room. I had them however tied up in paper, as they are a little too suggestive uncovered, for sleepy observation. I must not neglect mentioning the rather insignificant addition to our party, in the shape of a tourtourelle, bought when we were going up the river for half a piastre from a native who had brought the little unfledged thing to the boat. Georgette undertook the care and nurture of it - and we named him Mena after the first historical king. He has grown and thrived and is now quite a
character, and insists upon being present when we eat, and has a special predelection for the buiscuit that are served for afternoon tea, and he sometimes grows very impatient for it, flies into the room, and on to the table, running up and down, fluttering his wings, and saying, "Why don"t you hurry up that tea".

Another very warm day, and we devoted the morning to hunting antiquities. At one of the shops we fell in with an Englishman by the name of Chester, who has spent 21 winters in Egypt - and has some accurate knowledge of antiquities - as he buys for the British Museum, and Ashmolean in Oxford - he had promised to come and look at our purchases. Then we went to Mohammed Mohassibs, and bought some things. These men never keep their best things on exhibition - nor do they produce them unless they are very sure of their customers. They keep them in safe hiding either in or out of the house. This morning Mohassib took us into a small back room up stairs - with a bed in it, and lifting one of the mattresses showed us two long mummy cloths with figures and inscriptions on them. They were from the mummies of Amenophis 3d and his queen - and he asked $700 in our money, or 3500 francs for them. M.S. has a knowledge of these things, and pronounces generally as to what is spurious and genuine, and keeps an eagle eye on us, to see that we are not cheated - and when he says quietly, "you don"t want that Governor", Theodore will not buy. These
cloths were genuine, no doubt, and the query was, how were they found? Had the tomb of this kind lately been opened? and where are the other valuable things? It is very stirring and exciting to think of the constant digging and searching among the tombs across the river. Every Arab in Goornah I am told spends his night in this way. It is against all law - the government allows no digging or excavations - but they seem powerless to prevent it. It would be difficult to put such extensive territory under sufficient guard - and they have not the money to undertake thorough and intelligent excavations themselves. I feel in a rage about it when I think of it. In the meantime hundreds of hands are surreptitiously at work at it - valuable things are destroyed and injured by hasty and forbidden search. The beautiful, highly ornamented mummy head of a woman that Theodore bought, has had the back of it torn hastily off, and what has become of the rest of the case, and the mummy with its valuable things folded in its wrappings! These men dare not offer what they find, for sale openly - either they have to part with them at a moderate price, to two or three dealers in Luxor, who in their turn secrete them until a safe and advantageous opening offers itself - or - they sometimes make a secret sale directly to the tourist. It is soon known among this thieving fraternity, that a tourist is anxious to buy good things, and willing to pay for them - and this accounts for the one or two mysterious men, who are constantly squatting on the bank near us, and who if he catches the eye of us holds up some bag or packet to attract our curiousity. But M.S.
and the Captain ignore them, and they are are not allowed to be present themselves - and we do not notice them. We had intended this afternoon about 4 to row down to Karnac, 2 miles from here, and then ride over to the temples - but just as we were having tea on deck, Mr. Chester appeared and stayed some time talking and looking at our purchases. He says the papyrus is a portion of the Ritual of the Book of the Dead, but as there may be some other matter with it, advises T. to submit it to an expert in London, and says he will give him a card of introduction to the head of the Egyptian department of the Museum. After he went away, we had only time for a charming row of a mile or two. There are several dahabeahs here now - some bound up, and four like ourselves bound down, Mr. Chesters among the number. It looks very pretty and gay. After dinner M.S. came to us and asked if we would like to go up to his tent on the bank, as he had someone reading the Koran there - and explained that when at Luxor he always had this done. So up we went, and found chairs had been carried up for us and rugs - and sat for half an hour listening to three men seated on a rug, singing or intoning the Koran, with that swinging of the body which seems to be necessary to a recital of the Koran, Several Arabs were gathered about the door of the tent, M.S. and Rais Achmed were sitting on the ground in devout attitudes, occasionally responding to the reading by a slowly drawn out "Allah". The principal reader would recite incredibly fast for a time, then one or other of the men on either side of him would take it up, beginning in a strange high falsetto tone,
and sinking to the level of the intonation - occasionally breaking out in the same high key again. It was a strange, and lovely scene - through the tent door the broad river below us lay in one silver sheen of moonlight, and far away glimmered the chain of western hills, which still hide in their stony bosoms so many secrets we would like to know, and which have witnessed centuries ago, so many burial ceremonies of the great and royal dead.

This has been a lazy and delightful day. it has been hot - and this morning we walked in the town, or rather the rest did while I had a donkey. We went again through the temple. In the afternoon, I stayed quietly at home - and about 4, Theodore and Mary crossed the river, and visited Medinet Abou, returning by moonlight. They pronounced it a charming time of day to see the ruins to the best advantage. This evening we have had our second "fantasia" - and very pretty we were with our palm decked boat, and the coloured lights from bow to stem, and up and down the rigging - with Bengal lights and occasional rockets, and a large, if not very select audience along the bank. We are to make one last excursion across the river tomorrow - for alas! the days at Luxor must come to an end, as did those at Assouan.

An early start across the river for a last visit to Medinet Abou - the sun, however was hours before us, and I thought we should
have been shrivelled up by its burning rays - but, in spite of it, the beautiful ride had its charms, across the green fragrant fields, with the golden mountains beyond, and the Colossi sitting in their eternal strangeness on the border of the desert. After wandering and looking about sometime, M.S. brought up an Arab who he said was a man to be trusted, and who had dealt for years in antiquities, etc. etc. We were conducted to the seclusion of one of the side chambers, and posting Jacoub at the entrance to give us warning of the coming of anyone, the Arab produced from some of the inner depths of his dress an exquisite little wooden statuette about 3 inches high of a naked boy with the side lock worn by young princes, with hieroglyphs and scrolls on the base - reminding me of the wooden statuettes I had seen in the Boulak two years ago. The price he demanded was enormous, and Theodore would not give it. He swore he had found it three days before at El Assassif, a certain part of the necropolis. We were then taken to a tomb lately excavated near the Ramesseum - the paintings were brilliantly fresh, though they were two thousand or more years old - but very crude. There were two chambers - and the heat in them was intense. Our guide said he would like to own this tomb for a home to live in! all his people lived in tombs he said - they were cooler in summer and warmer in winter. We then paid a farewell visit to the Ramesseum, and rode home in time for lunch - in the afternoon going to some very amusing races, got up by the English club at Luxor - camel - buffalo - donkey races - and amusing matches - a large concourse of people - so many tourists
plainly telling of the presence of one of Cook's steamers. I had a donkey going and coming - and Mary and Theodore made a long detour through the town home, while I under the care of M.S. and two of the men, came directly home, passing on the Grand Duke Peter and his wife of Russia, who are spending the winter at the Luxor Hotel, nice, ordinary looking young people. This evening who should ask entrance but the Arab dealer of the morning, who brought his young prince which Theodore bought at a great reduction from the original price.

Our last morning at Luxor found us very busy, immediately after breakfast Beato, the photographer came to take the picture of our men and dahabeah. The sun was intensely hot, the awnings having to be lifted, he was in a great hurry to get back to his atelier and everybody seemed excessively stupid about it. After he had gone Theodore strolled into the the town which he reported very quiet and stupid, as all the dahabeahs but two, and Cook's steamers had gone off early. After lunch we went to sit on the deck in the shade of a narrow awning, while preparations were made to get away, and about 3 o'clock we put off, firing a farewell gun, and receiving a parting salute - as we were well going and had passed the post office, a man came out and shouted there was a letter for Theodore - so we pulled up and Theodore and M.S. went ashore in the felucca, returning in a few minutes indignant, as the letter had proved to be for some one on an English dahabeah. M.S.
was particularly ruffled - he stalked the deck, his eyes flashing and said in plain English, "that man is one damn fool". "Why Mahommed" I said, " I didn"t know you had learned that kind of English," and with the pleasant laugh so characteristic of him, he said, "Yes, Madame, he is one damn fool"! We dropped down the river as far as the pleasant beach at Karnac - where donkeys were waiting for us, and soon rode off through the village, which is rather pretty with its palms, acacias, and scent trees, but it swarms with dirty, naked children who pursued us demanding baksheesh - and with wolfish looking dogs snarling and barking at us from the roofs and walls. The vastness and gigantic size of the ruined temples impressed me more today than before - where else, can such a confusion of mightly ruins be found? We stood in the great hall of columns of Seti Ist, for the last time, and looked up at the gigantic far away capitals, against the soft blue sky - they represent the expanded lotus flower, and their enormous edges seem almost to touch - many of them still brilliant in color -and on each side vista after vista of great columns, and we amongst them seemed like insignificant atoms. As everywhere in these Egyptian temples, and in a greater degree here, the mind is oppressed with the thought of the enforced toil and labour necessary to such achievement, of the thousands of toiling workmen, slaves and captives, and in such a climate. By good right, these vast halls should be haunted continually by their wails of suffering and despair - and how stupendous the might, and how insolent the power of those old kings, who could command such results!
The ride home in the gloaming through the fragrant fields was delighful, and when we reached the bank of the river, the Nubia with her bright lights lying below, looked such a pleasant welcome to us. Mohammed Ali came out with the lantern to light us down the rough bank, and two or three others came to lead my donkey down and help me to dismount, and Rais Achmed with the rest about him, stood ready to help us in. Always on coming home in this way there are so many brown hands held out to help and welcome, that I always think of the the line from that sweet hymn "yet there are hands stretched out to draw me near". Theodore and Mary had been counting upon going once more to the temple by moonlight - but alas! the moon hid herself behind clouds - and there was nothing to do but stay at home - play our game of dominoes, and write our journals!

After a night rendered very restless by the barking and howling of innumerable dogs, we got up to find a beautiful morning, but alas! a steady north wind blowing. After two or three hours of rowing, the men gave it up, and we drifted helplessly with wind and current until lunch, when the motion being so great, we tied up to the bank, so that we might eat in peace. The only events of the day have been passing an English dahabeah on her proud career up the river - and a walk of 3 miles Theodore was able to get, during which he encountered a holy dervish, with whom he stopped to talk through M.S.
A beautiful but uneventful day - with little head wind and calms. The men have rowed vigorously and faithfully, and we are now tied up for the night, having made 42 miles!
A cloudy morning followed by a day of soft southerly wind, and occasionally real sprinkles of rain, enough to send us down two or three times from the deck, brought us 35 miles on our way.

We went hard and fast upon a sand bank last night, within sight of Balliana, and after much effort got off, but anchored where we were, as the night was very dark, and came up to the town early this morning. We found the "Eva" a big dahabeah with two or three American men, which lay near us several days at Luxor, lying here just behind us. She is the nicest most luxuriant boat we have seen on the river. The morning was overcast which made it very pleasant for us, and we were soon in our saddles riding through the clean picturesque town, and out upon the wide green fields, bound for Abydos 6 miles or more away. The valley here is very wide, from 6-9 miles and the crops exceedingly rich - from the river to the foot of the desert land, barley, wheat, lupins etc. stand in unbroken luxuriance. At regular distances, rude pedestals of mud and straw, some four feet high are placed, on which
men were sitting guarding the crops. What a delicious morning it was, and what a charming ride, through that soft air, fragrant with the blossoming crops. At one time the rain fell smartly, and we had to put up our umbrellas. All along the narrow path through the fields, men, women, children, buffaloes, camels etc. were hurrying to the market at the town of Arabat, which is built over the mounds of old Abydos, they made pretty pictures streaming along one after the other - and we were obliged to turn out of our way sometimes to avoid the camels. Just at the edge of this town stands the temple of Seti Ist that prince of builders, its exquisite sculptures making it the most beautiful temple in Egypt. Here we spent the morning and lunched - and our lunch table was spread in the narrow corridor on one of the walls of which, the famous tablet of Abydos is sculptured - containing a list of the kings beginning with Menes, and ending with Seti. We chose the semi-darkness of this corridor, dirty and dusty as it was, as a high wind had sprung up, driving the dust in a blinding fashion. It fortunately fell however before we started out in the blinding heat for a visit to the little that remains of the splendid temple of Ramesses 2d. We did not undertake the ride further on to the tombs of Kom-es-Sultan - a locality which disputes with Philae to contain the tomb of Osiris. So we turned home for the long ride back - and as we passed the Eva, looked down upon her cool shaded deck, where the men were smoking, and felt ourselves very hot and dusty. By 5 o'clock we were off, making the distance, in spite of the wind to Girgeh, about dark,
a distance of 8 miles. We sat on deck, watching the play of distant lightning. Just as we landed a sharp north wind began to blow, which looks ominous for our progress tomorrow. A Cook's steamer, and two dahabeahs are lying here, and this evening Theodore and Mary had the audacity to visit the former.

The wind blew a howling gale all night, and a hurricane today. Of course we have not moved. Theodore and Mary went off for a long walk in the afternoon, and I and Georgette and M.S. were rowed down to the town in the felucca, carrying my saddle. A wretched little donkey was found, so small that I could almost sit down upon him without help, and as thin as he was small. But he protested in plainest language against the saddle, so another was fetched, a little bigger but no less miserable, who in his turn protested against the bit, so it was taken out, and he was ignominiously led or rather dragged and as he frequently stumbled, it was just as well for me that he had a stout man to support him. We went through the uninteresting bazaar, and through the market where a fair was in progress, and a merry go round, and conjurors were busy. We paused for a few moments on the outside of a large circle of people who were gathered about a 'story teller". I would much have liked to have understood what he said, the crowd were following his words and movements with an undivided attention. Then M.S. took me to the door of an old Mosque, which he said I would not be allowed to enter, some peculiar sanctity forbidding a a woman to
