enter there. Clearly woman has but little place in the Mohammedan scheme of religion. Some men lounging on the top of the flight of steps seemed inclined to resent my even looking in - but M.S. in a lofty manner rather wiped them away and I had a glimpse into the dusky interior, with its walls quite covered with most lovely old blue and white Saracenic tiles. Girgeh is an important town with 13,000 inhabitants, and shows one beautiful minaret.

We have had strong winds all day, but have made about 21 miles. Three or four up bound dahabeahs have passed us. Theodore and Mary got quite a walk this afternoon. We are now tied up for the night near a little mud village with a background of palms - and quite a long level bit of beach. After we were made fast, I got out and walked up and down, followed by a crowd of naked and ragged children, shrieking in their pleasant little voices - "baksheesh Howadji" - "baksheesh Howadji". Flocks are coming home from the fields - camels - donkeys, buffaloes and goats - women carrying water from the river - a fire seen here and there in the village, with its blue smoke rising. The wind is rough tonight - the rudder squeaks - and the felucca bangs against us, and the tired men are all asleep.

Reached Sohag - having made about 5 miles - Theodore is annoyed at staying here for the night, when he thinks we should have
gone on. Just as we neared the town, a large boat laden with men who proved to be prisoners bound for the prison here, under the charge of soldiers, came across the river and landed. M.S. calls them 'steal people" and he and Räis Achmed are plainly afraid of this part of the river, which is notorious for thieving maurauders. We are beginning to feel a little anxious about reaching Cairo by the 28th, when our lease expires.
Made 12 miles under a strong north wind.

A morning of delightful calm. The men rowed from day light to 12 o'clock, and we are now at Aboutig 15 miles from Assiout. We overtook Mr. Chester in the "Rudder Grange" and he made us a visit this evening with his friend Mr. Cooper - a sturdy blond, pink and white young Englishman. We showed our beautiful Sphinx and little prince, with both of which he seemed properly impressed - and said the former would grace any European Museum. He was most alarming however in his predictions of custom house dangers.

Another calm morning. Our good sailors brought us to Assiout about noon. Theodore has been so much bored by our slow progress, that
he takes our movements with the most gloomy limitations - and soon after breakfast when I saw through the glass the trees and minarets of Assiout, and announced my discovery, I was laughed to scorn, and he offered to bet $1000 lbs. I was wrong. But here we are! Soon after lunch we mounted our donkeys and went to the American Mission taking our spare books and magazines to Mr. And Mrs. Alexandre. (I wonder what they will think of "John Ward, Preacher".) We took Jacoub with us, so that Mr.Alexandre could explain to him what Theodore was willing to do with him in the way of schooling, if he wished to accept it. But I think the idea is too big for him. We found the four little Alexandres pale, recovering from diphtheria. After a pleasant call we said goodbye, and rode up the Mountain to the the justly celebrated view of the wide plain. While the rest climbed to the very top, I sat still on my donkey, content with the beautiful scene stretched out below me. The wide valley so richly cultivated, the picturesque town with its mosques, domes and minarets lay bathed in a delicious afternoon light. The air was crisp - like one of our early spring days, and fragrant with blossoming crops - coming home, we passed a funeral procession - the women wailing as usual. One middle aged woman following the bier, was sobbing with such heart felt sobs - it was the sound of a heart truly bereft!

We made about 27 miles this A.M. much of the time with one sail in use, spinning along in a most encouraging manner. But soon
the wind pulled out ahead, and tonight we are anchored in mid river, literally, "rocked in the cradle of the deep".

We started early, and made about 4 miles before the wind grew so strong that we laid by where we now are, Mr. Chester near us, and sand flying all the afternoon so we could only now and then catch a glimpse of him.

The "Rudder Grange" was close by our side when Georgette drew my curtains this morning, and the lofty cliffs of Gebel Abou-faydah were towering above our heads. M.S. reported at breakfast, that we had only made four miles from last nights anchorage - and the wind was already blowing hard. After breakfast Theodore went ashore and joined Mr. Chester for a stroll along the cliffs - while Mary and I stayed on deck, watching through the glass the numerous birds who make their nests in the crevices of the rocks - sometimes we would swing so near to these perpendicular cliffs, as almost to touch. The wind blew harder and harder - and we made for the opposite shore which was low and sandy, and there made fast. Mr. Chester followed us, and he and Mr. Cowper came in their small boat to pay us a visit, and we asked them to stay to lunch, which they did - so that the dull day was most pleasantly broken. They brought over some curious beads, and many scarabs, and an interesting statuette - and we talked of antiquities
of Egypt, of books and authors! We are about 4 miles from Manfaloot. All the afternoon the wind howled, and the sand flew. We let down our canvass sides to protect us, but it penetrated every crack. The waves rushed by like waves of the sea - and we rock from side to side - the aimless rudder creaks - and it is impossible to secure the felucca so that she will not bang against us. We feel the emergency is so trying we must meet it as cheerfully as we can. I want to get to Cairo now to have a few days before leaving for Italy.

Last night was really awful. In the evening the Captain found we were sinking too much in the soft sand, and with great difficulty worked us out 50 ft. from shore where we anchored - though the current was strong, the wind was so violent, that our bow faced down stream, and in the fluctuations of the wind, we would turn a little and then back again, bringing up with a jerk on the anchor. After getting into bed and trying to sleep for two hours, I gave it up and lighted my candle, which burned until half past two o'clock. What with the wind, the tramping and rushing about of the sailors, the banging of boats and rudder, sleep was impossible - the crew were up all night, and Räis Achmed was only too thankful to pull out from our dangerous position when the wind lulled, an hour before daylight. The men have worked like good fellows at their oars today, and we have made 24 miles, and are lying near Rhoda - hoping to reach Beni Hassan tomorrow in time to do the tombs and be off again before night,
for no one wishes to stay a night near that town of ill repute.

Our slumbers last night were rather disturbed by our guards who seemed to think it necessary to fire off a rifle now and then as a warning to the neighborhood - for several nights now, we have had three or four men on guard. We awakened to a calm lovely day, though a very warm one. The men rowed vigourously, and brought us to Beni Hassan soon after eleven o'clock. Lunch was hurried, donkeys commanded by stentorian lungs from the dahabeah, and by 12 o'clock we were in the felucca for the opposite shore, where donkeys, two soldiers with their rifles, and a vociferating crowd of the most villainous looking Arabs I ever saw, were waiting for us. The whole neighborhood of Beni Hassan has had a most evil reputation for years - and some years ago the old village of Beni Hassan was destroyed by order of the Government because of the thieving and turbulent character of its people - and from what we heard and saw of the inhabitants of the present village, the same heroic remedy should be resorted to, in regard to them. Certainly a more wicked and howling cortige than we had, I never saw. The soldiers must have accompanied us as a decoration, as they seemed incapable of quieting the donkey men and guides - and were utterly wanting in anything like dignity - and there was a constant exchange of hostilities between them. I saw one of the guides take a soldier by the neck and spin him almost off his feet. I expected to see him use his rifle, and I now have doubts of
the rifles being loaded. Our donkeys were the most wretched of their race, and as we took our way over the hot arid stoney path, we hoped the pilgrimage would soon be over. Two miles of it took us up to a lofty plateau from which a most enchanting view was had of the Nile valley for miles up and down the river. How brilliantly green the narrow ribbon like strips of cultivated land looked, with its frame of desert on either side! Arrived at the tombs, another shrieking scrimmage went on, while we waited indignant until the various guides settled some difficulty among themselves.

These Beni Hassan tombs of the 12th dynasty, marking one of the finest periods of art in Egypt, are so well known - every ordinary student of art is familiar with their graceful and elegant columns, prototypes of the Grecian Doric order of centuries later. The paintings too, are wonderfully rich in variety, and form with the tomb of Ti at Sakkarah the richest sources of all our knowledge of Egyptian life and manners of the earlier dynasties. But alas! how disappointing the actual sight of them! Such is the ruin caused, not by time, but by the ruthless hands of travellers from earliest times to our own. It is impossible to make out many of the figures, only familiarity with their representations in books, make them decipherable and the columns chipped and hacked, their bases almost wanting. It is hideous to think of it. One piece of vandalism dates but a few months back, and shows a square chasm in the stone, with its fresh surface. Since then, for the first time, these tombs have been placed under the care of guards. The thing that best repaid us was the wide outlook over that strange
country. It was so hot however, and our surroundings were so disagreeable that we only paused for a few moments after leaving the grottoes, for a look about us, but hurried down by a shorter and pleasanter way, avoiding the town, to the Nubia which had dropped down the river 3 miles and lay waiting for us. Several of our men came out some distance to meet us, and it was delightful to see their pleasant smiles of welcome and protection. When we arrived we found an audience of the same villainous looking men squatting about, and the Nubia several feet from shore, at the extreme limit of her gang plank. We were glad to dismount and take refuge in the cool and shady cabin. A tremendous row began when M.S. made his settlement with the guides, donkey men and soldiers - and when they saw signs of departure, several of them sprang into the water, and held the boat, our men unceremoniously took in the gang plank with 3 men on it, giving them a fine dip in the water - and Theodore put some cartridges in his pocket, and took his gun, and sat down in a conspicuous position with it, on the upper deck. At last we were off in the lovely, quiet afternoon, and sped away with a light wind and a fast current down to Minieh, where we are now lying, reading the letters and papers we found waiting for us in the P.O. This morning at breakfast, it being Washington's birthday I idly spoke of it to M.S. as one of our national "jours de fete", and he immediately hurried out with that childish eastern pleasure in small things, to warn the cook - as a consequence we had a particularly elaborate dinner, and an extraordinary construction in the way of a cake covered with pink icing, and resting in a nest of bonbons - crowned by a standard
with an attempt at an American flat at the top - all the handiwork of Cook Ibrahim. This, M.S. deposited on the table with a grand manner, saying, "C"est le gateau pour M. Washington". I plunged into it with a knife when the time came, and we found it a most uneatable mass of sponge cake and confiture, deadly sweet, so under cover of giving the crew a part in one National holiday, we sent most of it out to them, which they greatly enjoyed - and "Mr. Washington's flag" adorns our prow, to the great amusement of the crew.

A lovely calm, warm morning, developed a fine south wind, and we have made a splendid run of 50 miles, and are now lying 106 miles from Cairo. It has been a relief to see the men having a day of rest from their oars. The afternoon was enchanting, with a yellow sunset sky - the pink and blue colours filling all the east, and reflected in the calm water - the young moon now four days old making quite a radiance. We were on deck all the time - our white well filled sail carrying us swiftly through this scene of beauty. In the morning we had an exciting time - we had reached a place where the river spread broadly out, and as it is now quite low, there are seen as well as unseen sand banks - and a dozen or more working boats tacking backwards and forwards in the light wind - collision after collision seemed imminent, and only by the efforts of our giant second Captain, sided by the crew, prevented one of these heavy boats colliding with us - such shrieking and dashing about, and such grunts and groans from our
men as they actually put themselves as bumpers between the boats. We left a large part of our red and white streamer on the mast of another boat. Cooks new big steamer "Rameses the Great" came along in the midst of it, and stopping for a moment, chose another channel and went safely through. Then came a small Egyptian steamer, which went bravely on a sand bank and stuck there, until sometime in the afternoon I suppose, as she passed us just before evening.

A trying disappointing day - the north wind has blown - and most of the time we have been tied up to the bank - hiding our heads under our wings, poor things. The only incident has been seeing a hyena feeding on something, as we drifted near the eastern desert shore. The men rowed after the wind fell, from 6 to 9 o'clock - making 6 miles. Theodore is unhappy and discouraged.

Another day of north wind and hard pulling for our crew - and tonight we are within 5 miles of Beni-Soef, with 78 miles between ourselves and Cairo - and only two days left of our contract time! The weather is much cooler. I never tire of watching the crew make the nightly landing - in a moment their oars are shipped, the yawning chasms in which they have been seated and standing all day are closed with the trap doors, the chain is made ready, and Mahomet Ali graceful and agile as a fawn, stands in the prow with it in his hand, and as the
boat touches, over he goes, and followed by two or three of the others, the boat is held until the stake is driven in and we are fast. Tommy's little stove casts a comfortable fireside glow along the deck - the unfailing dish of broken dry bread and lentil soup is smoking on it. Esne shoulders his pail and staff, and goes off at once to search for milk - the rest of the men get up the awning in a twinkling - the big lantern is lighted and hung - the tired fellows tying their shawls over their heads, sit down to rest, and everything is quiet and homelike. Not often after a hard days row, do they sing now - but after their supper wrap themselves in their rugs, and let us hope, lie down to pleasant dreams - more likely to a dreamless sleep.
We have been tied to the bank or floating most of the day. After the sun went down the wind fell, and the men rowed until 10 o'clock, making about 10 miles the whole day.

A calm hot day - our men have worked magnificently, and we are now about 12 miles of Cairo. We have packed and settled a great many things and have spent most of the day on deck in spite of the heat. The Meydoum pyramid appeared early this morning - then Dashour and finally the well know outlines of Gizeh - and I began to realize that the delicious Nile life was over. It made us very uncomfortable to see the men sitting in the intense sunlight hour after hour working
so hard - but they have all felt it to be the last day, and were under the excitement of the last spurt. The 2d captain stood at his helm like a splendid bronze statue - and had piles of shawls and cloaks on top of his head for protection. Occasionally he would descend to the lower deck and take the place of some weary sailor for a time, and it seemed as if his magnificent strength told at once and he would put new life in the crew. The singer sang his best songs continually, and got off some extraordinary vocal gymnastics. M.S. even took a hand at the oars once in a while - and two or three times Räis Achmed took a pull himself. About 5 o'clock a fine south wind came up - both sails were hoisted - the tired men put away their oars - the hatches went down, and we were glad to see them resting. We had hoped to stop at Sakkarah for a day - but we are too much behind time. I have told M.S. some days ago, that when we got into Cairo I should give the men a good dinner - with the idea of which they are well pleased. Soon after 5 o'clock I descried the minarets of the Citadel, and for a time, as the moon was bright, we thought we could make Cairo this evening. But the river was so low, and so many sand banks, to be avoided, that the Captain pulled up at Bedrasheyn for the night, having made over 50 miles today.

We arrived at 9 o'clock this morning - the quiet south wind of last night has increased and developed into a respectable kamseen, as we drew up beneath the high encircling walls of a palace enclosure
on the Cairo side, the waves were rushing past us, and the driving wind carried everything movable before it. General and formal congratulations were exchanged amongst all, from Rais Achmed and M.S. down to the crew on our safe arrival. Theodore and M.S. at once went ashore and drove into town for our mail, and to secure rooms and money. While Mary and I, having survived the misery of dismantling the dahabeah, and watched the last disposition of our many belongings, and newly acquired possessions and antiquities, went on deck where the close awnings protected us from the stifling hot wind. Before I was ready to leave the cabin, Hassan came and said the men were at their dinner, but they would not eat until I came out. Surprised at the celerity of the preparations for the feast, and the hour chosen, I went out and found the lower deck enclosed with its awnings, a veritable table occupying most of it, and the men actually seated in chairs and on benches about it! looking so conscious and silly, but as happy as children. They rose at once, all their white teeth shining in their smiling brown faces, and began a triple cheer, led off by Esne, ending with "tink you, tink you, my lady" repeated again and again, and followed by some undistinguishable English sentence, in which, I suppose, M.S. had coached them. Then they sat down and began devouring such a meal as they never had before. There were platters of good meat and vegetables up and down the table - two chickens, good bread, a great pudding of rice and milk, oranges and coffee - and I don't think a grain of rice, or a shred of meat was left on the table. Then they had cigarettes, and renewed
cheering - and Esne made a dance around the table, and up the gangway to thank me again, with his wild gesticulations. I was so sorry Theodore missed the pleasant sight. He and M.S. soon came back, with a huge mail, and the unsatisfactory news that we must go for the night to the Continental Hotel - as our rooms at Shepheards would not be ready until tomorrow. Then began the distribution of money and presents to all the men - after which ceremony all our possessions were transferred to carts and carriages, we bade a melancholy farewell to all, and took one last fond look at the gallant little Nubia, which had been our home for two months - and about which so many interesting and delightful memories will always cling. Each man as we said goodbye and shook hands, carried our hands near but not to the mouth, and then to the forehead, and their "good bye Sitt" I shall not soon forget. Mahomet Ali and Jacoub went with us to the hotel, and worked like Trojans. Cairo could hardly be seen as we drove along the streets, the hot wind was driving so much dust along the streets - and the ladies in the cool marble courts and corridors of this very pleasant looking hotel, were in their silks and muslins.

We were all glad to come to this famously comfortable hotel, the very centre of Cairo life to the tourist, and we took possession of a beautiful new appartment. The house is very full - and the usual amusing tide of life characteristic of the place goes and comes. It is warm enough to sit on the terrace in the evening in a light dress, and
without wraps. A council of war was held today - and all our plans are changed. My cherished idea of spending several days at the Mena Hotel at the Pyramids has to be resigned - as no rooms can be had there for weeks - so in place of staying in Egypt for 10 days longer, we sail next Monday for Brindisi in one of the Austrian Lloyd boats - being afraid to trust the Italian Rabitino line to Naples. We are rushing now - dozens of things to be done - and no time to do them in.

We had a long morning at the Boulak Museum which was closed when we were here 2 months ago. I suppose it will always be called the Boulak, although it is no longer in that town, but in the Gezireh Palace. We went over to it at half past 9 o'clock, and I am completely tired this evening. Never did the rich treasures contained in this Museum seem so interesting and fascinating. The space and beauty of their present quarters is a great contrast to the limited old quarters at Boulak. This palace is very large and really beautiful, in spite of its rather gaudy decorations - the grounds are extensive, and it must soon be an unrivalled museum. In the afernoon we went to the Bazaar, and then drove to the Citadel, and went through the Mosque of Mohamet Ali - it was almost night - and the court and mosque with their twinkling lights were very effective.

I got up very early this morning, and took a little bout at packing before breakfast. Georgette, who has never been very useful, is going directly to Paris - and I am now able to get on without her. I gave the nice little Mena to her, with some extra money to pay his expenses. After an early breakfast, we drove directly to Gizeh, to a private dealer in antiquities, where we stayed until 12 o'clock, bringing home some charming things. More packing then, and general adieux - and I rushed off in the carriage with M.S. for a visit to the Mosque of Amru, away off in old Cairo - a vast melancholy tumbling down place - the oldest in Cairo, where at a certain day in the Ramadam, a service is held, to which come devotees from all parts of Egypt. This is the only time of the year, when it is visited by Musselmans - now, it is all solitude, and dust, and decay - I treasured up all I saw, going and coming, as among my last views of beloved old Egypt. We were back at the hotel quite in time, and were soon being packed in with our luggage for the station. Poor M.S., I hated to say goodbye to him - and I left a blessing and every good wish for him. Tonight we are sad and tired - and yet half glad to be free from all the entourage that had grown up about us - and which was always arousing our sympathy, and giving us a sense of responsibility. M.S. with his own strange, childish eastern ways and animal like devotion - and all the good fellows of the dahabeah, who after we reached Cairo, were always turning up, for nothing in the world apparently, but to beam upon us
affectionately once more. Whenever we went out, we would see one or two of them in the crowd of hangers on before the hotel - we had nothing more to give them, but a smile, a wave of the hand, or a kind word, for which they seemed so grateful. But it was always a prolonged goodbye - and a feeling as if something more might be done for the poor fellows - and Mary and I decided we should be mental and emotional wrecks if this thing went on much longer. Now, life seems more quiet and simple - and Mary and I feel so happy and independent without Georgette - we have a big gloomy room, lighted by 2 candles, with 2 little beds in it, and we fell like school girls off for a lark! We sail in the Enterpe tomorrow at 9 o'clock and I do trust the voyage will be a good one. I do not like to think of the dreadful one we made two years ago from this port - "I have such fear, I know no hope"!

div.dateline: Naples - Italy Saturday - March 8th. Grand Hotel.
div.p:
We arrived this morning by the night train from Brindisi, travelling in a coupe lit for the first time, which though not very comfortable is really less tiresome and fatiquing than the long day journey. My prophetic fears about the voyage across the Mediterranean were only too well fulfilled. We found a delightfully clean little ship, with not too many passengers. Major Nott and his family and Mr. Sampson, of Sampson, Low and Co. London, who has been in Cairo some time with Stanley, and was on his way back to London, with the precious manuscript in his portmanteau. We had one good day and
night, but on the second evening a gale began to blow, which has hardly stopped, then followed two most wretched days and nights. The ship pitched and rolled tremendously - Mary was very ill in her room all the time - and I stopped in my berth, afraid to venture out - Theodore and Major Nott were among the few who were not ill. We were 8 hours late at Brindisi and the P.&O. due there at the same time we were, did not get in until the next day. We had to spend the day at Brindisi, and with the help of a fire, a comfortable room overlooking the quays, and two or three good books, did not have half a bad time of it. I am so happy to find myself once more in this delicious Italy. We have charming rooms on the 1st etage of this hotel, and such a view! the Mediterranean just on the other side of the broad street - the unrivalled scenery of the bay of Naples before us, good beds, a delightful table - and innumerable charming things to be done. After a good breakfast we took a drive to the bankers for letters, and then our old favorite drive up the heights back of Naples and across the Posolippo. What an enchanting air! and what an elixir it seemed after the soft air of Egypt! We got out of the carriage and walked quite a distance along that fine road, stopping to hang over the walls, and gaze at that beautiful world spread like a map beneath us. I read one of dear Ettie Whalings charming letters, and wished over and over again that she and Mary were with me, to help enjoy all that beauty. Mary is enthusiastic over everything she sees.

Spent the morning in the Musee - the building was very cold, and we were glad to get out into the genial air. We went through the Pompeian rooms - they were filled with the usual Sunday crowd of peasants and small people - and although they were odorous, and not to be approached too nearly, I was much interested in their quiet, and genuinely hearty interest in every thing they saw. The American sailor boys were there in full force - as three ships of the "White Squadron" as it is called over here, are in port at Castelamore. For the first time I saw the room of the Herculaneum Papyri - the blackened rolls of which did not look as if any information could be got out of them. They were all numbered and lay on shelves around the room. There were 3 or 4 glass cases standing on supports in the middle of the room, containing a very nicely contrived apparatus for unwrapping and mending them. Steam is introduced into this case, and by a complicated method the rolls are straightened and deciphered. They are black and charred, the writing showing on their black surfaces. This "library" belonged to a private gentleman of Herculaneum, and consisted of about 3000 volumes or rolls - many of which have been deciphered. How it stirs the imagination to think of the dignified repose of that ancient library, now buried from 50 to 100 feet under the lava that rushed down the sides of Vesuvius on that dreadful night A.D. 79. In the afternoon the wind blew so hard and cold and Theodore, not well we stayed in doors - our charming sitting room, with its bright wood fire, and its three windows looking out upon the drive, crowded with carriages
and brilliant occupants, was not a bad place in which to spend an afternoon.
This morning opened with a heavy gale and rain, which continued until the afternoon, when we went out to the bankers for letters and visited some curiosity shops.
Mary was not well this morning, so that no excursions could be arranged. Theodore and I went again to the Museum, and in the afternoon had a drive.

Mary better, but not yet able to go out. The doctor thinks she will be all right in a day or two. Theodore and I drove to S. Martino. I remember it when I was here years ago. The old Monastery with the fortress of San Elmo, dominates the height of San Elmo, and is one of the most conspicuous figures of the city. A long drive through the busy and picturesque streets and a climb backwards and forwards, on one side looking down upon the varied roofs and terraces and gardens - on the other high walls of masonry or rock, pierced in places with staircases leading to the level above, from the tops of which trees and gardens and houses look down upon you, to the level of which the next turn brings you. This characteristic feature of Naples,
is delightful - and each rise in the road reveals more and more its magnificent entourage of mountains, pictureque coasts and sea - making it the most beautiful city in the world - all this, and the sunny spring-like morning seemed too enchanting to be real. This Carthusian Monastery of S. Martino suppressed like all the others now in Italy, still harbours five of the old monks, who live in retirement in one part of it, and manufacture the Chartreuse which has such a world wide reputation. We happened upon a very bright and interesting guide, who knew just what we wanted to see, and allowed us to see it in peace. There is a great charm to me in these deserted convents, and I like to picture the kind of life that went on in them when they were in their prime. I should like to have had hours to spend in these deserted courts and cloisters and halls. It was begun in 1325, and rebuilt in the 17th century. The church and sacristy are magnificent with mosaics and marbles and carved wood - the most important painting in the church being the altar piece - the Descent from the Cross, by Spagnoletta, his masterpiece I believe. We stood a long time on the little balconies of the Belvidere, looking out from their airy height upon the wondrous scene before us - just beneath us was the well kept terraced gardens of the monks with their prim walks and allies. In the afternoon still having poor Mary in the house, we drove to the heights of Capodimonte, where I had never before been - we were too late for the Museo, for which I was sorry for I wanted to see the collection of the old porcelain of Capdimonte; the drive about the extensive park was lovely.
Sorrento - Hotel Tramontana

I have been quite ill and confined to the house 3 days. Theodore and Mary, who seems to have transferred her ailments to me - have been busy - one day to Vesuvius - another to Pompeii. This morning the Doctor thought I could come over here - but a heavy gale began in the night, and the sea was dashing over the wall all along the quay in front of the hotel. The clouds lifted about noon however, and we hoped the storm was over - and we left at 2 o'clock by rail to Castelamore - but by the time we reached there the rain was again falling in torrents, and there was nothing to do but pack ourselves in a close carriage, and start out for the charming drive to Sorrento. I felt very impatient and disappointed. We came to the Hotel Tramontana, where we had telegraphed for rooms - and as we drove into the dripping court, the windows showed the heads of many morose looking and disgruntled tourists behind their panes. Our rooms are really palatial, looking from my room through the long drawing room, and beyond into Mary's the view is really distant. The windows overlook the sea, which seems to be all one with the gray sky, and nothing of the glorious world beyond can be seen. A bright fire was burning in the sitting room, and before this we made a little encampment of tables and easy chairs.

The rain was pouring all the morning - we improved the time writing letters. In the afternoon the rain stopped, and we had a
charming drive to the Deserto a monastery commanding a magnificent view. After dinner we went down to the ball room, made in the rock under the hotel, to see some men and women in their picturesque costumes dance.

This morning opened dismally enough with heavy clouds, and very high wind. All our arrangements made yesterday by telegram for coming here had to be changed. We proposed driving to Pajano, and there taking a boat to Amalfi - this would have been delightful - but the water was out of question in such a gale as this. So again everything had to be countermanded - and Theodore pointed out to me with renewed vigour, how foolish it was to spend more time on this Amalfi project. But I fought stoutly for it, as I was very averse to leave this part of Italy for the third time without a visit here, to Paestum and Ravello. As it was necessary to drive back to Castelamare, and thence to La Cava, and from there here, as we could no longer consider one other route we came to a compromise, and I said, if on reaching Castelamare it should rain, I would give up the whole scheme, and we would take the train back to Naples. So we packed into a big carriage with three good horses, and started. The very moment I thought the rain would begin. As we clattered over the stony streets of Castelemare, Theodore looked at me as if he thought I might relent, and said, "Is it to be La Cava", and I said "yes", and we all laughed, and the order
was given. The clouds hung low about Vesuvius and the wind almost tore our hats off our heads; but we held on our way, and soon the interest of the scene began to enthral us, and we became more and more charmed. We were driving through the country south of Vesuvius, and drawing near the mountains - the rugged heights crowned with ruined towns of castle and monastery - the plain richly cultivated - Pompeii lay between us and Vesuvius - we passed through Pagani, a large town of 15,000 inhabitants, with industries, and very prosperous. The approach to La Cava was beautiful. It is a picturesque town lying in a valley - a favorite resort for the Neapolitans in the summer and autumn. We stopped for luncheon, and to rest the horses, at a charming little hotel of excellent reputation, the Albergo di Loudra", and were delighted with it. In the dining room hung large prints of Bryant and Longfellow. But the beauty of the town was only seen on leaving it. A long street of arcades leads through it to a wild and romantic valley, very narrow, on one side of which runs the railway from Naples to Salerno over a fine viaduct. Every turn of the splendid road revealed some new beauty - before, behind us, and on each side. The steep hillsides and cliffs were actually yellow with cowslips - and everywhere the grass was drifted over with daisies, like a fall of snow - sweet purple violets nodded their heads amongst them, and purple anemones fringed the banks and walls. We passed the town of Vietri, lying high above us, and turning to the right, leaving the road to Salerno, we soon had an excellent view of the beautiful bay of Salerno, with its town at the waters edge, far below us. Then the magnificent road began to ascend
and in spite of clouds, giving us superb views of the encircling mountains, the sun here and there striking their summits and sides with a shaft of light sent through the heavy clouds above them. The most enchanting villages in the valleys - and clinging to the hillsides - with their picturesque diversity of roofs, outside stair cases and arches, and terraced gardens. Lemon trees occupied every square inch of these, from the waters edge almost to the top of the cliffs. The sea, far far below us, was dashing against the rocks, throwing up clouds of spray , and farther out, the white crested waves were chasing each other in. As we drove along the headlands, the wind seemed as if it would lift the carriage, and dash it against the rocks. The descent was beautiful and inspiriting, with all that wild accompaniment of wind and black cloud. At regular intervals along the coast began to appear strange square watch towers, built I believe, by Charles Vth for protection against pirates. When almost within sight of Amalfi the rain began and poured in torrents with thunder and lightning. The carriage was hastily closed, and waterproofs donned. Our arrival was very funny. We were stopped down on the little quay for 20 minutes, because there was a boat hauled across the street! Many dozen stout arms however, soon got it out of the way, and we proceeded a little farther under dark arches and vaulted streets, where every inch of room seemed to be occupied by boats, which had been pulled up out of reach of the furious surf. To our consternation the carriage stopped at the base of the cliff, and a polite hotel clerk with courteous manners came to meet us, and said in broken English that we must take
"only a little walk of perhaps five minutes to the hotel"! We looked up as well as the rain would allow us, to a vanishing vista of stone steps, and courageously shouldered our umbrellas, and set out upon our pilgrimage up to the Albergo dei Cappucini, a suppressed monastery of olden times, built half in the face of the cliff, and now metamorphosed into an hotel. As we climbed up the 250 steps, we paused once in a while to get our breaths, and look out upon glimpses of the wide prospect - and when we arrived at the entrance, and were shown into a long low vaulted corridor, as white as white wash could make it, with unmistakeable English luggage, interspersed with bath tubs, and peeped into the really pretty and comfortable little bedrooms, which used to be the barren cells of the monks, we felt quite repaid for our trouble. Theodore was put into one of these little cells, each one of which had a bit of enclosed balcony in front of it, making it a kind of tiny sitting room. They were furnished with little brass beds, white toilet tables and pretty chintz, and were really rather attractive. Mary and I were taken through a devious narrow corridor, and came out upon a broad stone staircase leading down into a great hall, where the table d'hôte stood ready for dinner, and beyond, we were shown into the prettiest of airy, comfortable sitting rooms, with a bright little fire burning in one corner, and a double bedded room opening from it with brass beds, chintz, muslin curtains etc. and candles burning on the toilet table. It was such a picture of comfort, with its quaint vaulted roof painted white! The dinner was served in the former refectory, with big crosses on the ceiling - and the drawing room was
made out of some of the cells. I have been sitting up in front of the fire for a long time - every one else has long been in bed - and the dash of the heavy surf is in my ears, on the rocks way below me - and I feel something as I imagine an eagle does in its nest!

The morning was threatening, and we dared not venture upon our excursion to Ravello. Mary and Theodore went down the cliff and into the town for a walk, and I went with the proprietor into the strange old chapel, where a snuffy, wheezy priest, the last survivor of the former monks, and so fat that I wondered how he could climb the stairs to this place, was holding a service, with a congregation of a dozen or more. We went into the gallery, and looked down on them, and my companion responded devoutly and sonorously through the service. Then I went out into the small cloister, with its pretty interlacing Moorish colonnade, and beyond to a great cave, with lofty projecting roof, where is a huge crucifix, and the two thieves on their crosses, making a most strange effect. Regular stations lead to it from the town below. Then I went out into the narrow terraces of the garden, which were full of flowers - gay geraniums, nasturtiums, hyacinths, mignonette and other flowers. The bees were busy among them, and the air so sweet with fragrance - but the clouds were so threatening I did not venture to climb to the orange grove above. The landlord told me that the monastery was founded in 1212 by Cardinal Pietro Capnano as a Cistercian convent - but passed in the 14th century into the hands of
the Capucins. It was twice suppressed - first under Murat, and again in the late general suppression of Italian monasteries. The views from the garden show Amalfi nestled in the cliffs, which seem to hang over her, and most of the houses look to be plastered on to the cliffs. The storm began after lunch with redoubled fury, the carriage was countermanded, and sat about the fire, in our queer little sitting room hung high above the rearing surf. Not a bad place in which to spend such an afternoon, but the disappointment of it all! after giving up four of our precious days to see all this coast - and then to find persistent storms and constant rain. And now, we must leave it all unseen, for we cannot wait longer, with no prospect of clearing weather, and must be off for Naples by 9 o'clock tomorrow morning. At dinner last night and then again tonight, Mr. and Mrs. Charles Kidder of Boston sat opposite to us. They say they have been waiting here a week to make the same excursions, we have been hoping to make - and they too are going tomorrow in despair. On the table by me as I write is a large dish of primroses and violets bought in this afternoon by our landlord.

We got off from Amalfi this morning. All last night the storm continued - and whenever I awoke the wind was howling and the sea roaring. It was like being at sea - and gave me a pleasant feeling of comfort to be lying in my pretty bedroom, and listen to the wild
tumult outside. In the morning when I got up the hail was rattling against the window, and forcing its way under it. For a time we feared it was too bad even for starting away - but the rain ceased fortunately for half an hour, and gave us time to climb down the interminable steps. We found the Kidders had already started - and we were hardly more than on our way when the rain began gently dropping and it was nothing but putting umbrellas up and down all the rest of the time. Down in the town the scene was very animated, and even exciting. All the inhabitants seemed to be collected in the narrow streets, watching the heavy surf as it plunged over the narrow beach and beat upon the little quay - and trying to put their boats in safe places. We had to make a great run for it in some places, as the waves would occasionally send the water over the road and against the cliff. But soon we were beyond its reach, and climbing over the same magnificent road we passed over two days ago - but alas! there was even less to be seen today - for rain and mists drowned everything. Great blue black clouds hung low upon the mountains - and sometimes we would drive right into them - and the wind howling about us, made it seem very wild and impressive. Our driver did not spare his horses, and to the music of his constant cracking of his whip, an accomplishment dear to the heart of an Italian coachman, and the cheerful caracolling of the irrepressible small boy atop of our luggage behind the carriage, we sped on and were at La Cava in time for lunch at 11:30. We fell in with the Kidders again, and were off in the same compartment for Naples by 2:30. I shall always remember the Italian
boy aforesaid - handsome as a picture - with his blue black hair, shining teeth, and russett red cheeks - alert and ready - jumping down from his perch again and again to pick a flower by the rodside for me, pattering through the wet in his cold bare feet - then clambering up again like a monkey, and breaking into a song. He was delightful, and I should like to have carried him off with me. I filled my bag at luncheon with a big red apple, with figs, and nuts and biscuit which I gave him as we were driving to the station, along with half a franc, and as Theodore had already given him 1 franc, he was a happy fellow, and his smiling face was a pleasant send off. Here we are established for the night in most charming rooms overlooking the quay, over which the tremendous surf is sometimes beating. It is pronounced all along this coast the most remarkable storm ever known. We took Mary to the Aquarium this afternoon - the Kidders came up and spent the evening, and said goodbye, and now we are all equipped for an early start to Rome in the morning.
Roma. Hotel Quirinale.

I was happy to be once more in this old city, where we arrived at 3 o'clock. The journey from Naples was delightful - through superb mountain scenery - the railway following very nearly the course of the ancient Via Appia. First, farewell glimpses of Mr. Vesuvius and Ischia, and that incomparable coast - then through the plain of the important river Volturno with the grand mountains sweeping up from it on either
hand in splendid majesty - their heights crowned here and there with supressed monasteries, ruined castles, crumbling towers and walls, with ancient Roman towns nestling along the cliffs and ravines. Then into the great plains of the Campania, an enormously fertile district under high cultivation now called the Terra di Lavoro, then through the valley of the Garigliano - then that of the Jacco, and at last we were approaching Rome with its Campagnia scenery - the Sabine and Alban Mountains on our right, with the arches of the Acqua Felice, and Acqua Marcia striding along the plain - and the Volscian Mountains with glimpses of the sea on our left.

If I were a man I should make an expedition through all this country. I would see many of the old towns with their polygonal walls, and old temples and ampitheatres - and I would visit those old monasteries especially that of Monte Casino, with the Abruggi Mountains lying opposite on the east across the narrow plain. This would be fascinating with its chapels and marbles, its carving and its pictures. It was founded by St. Benedict in 529 on the site of an ancient temple of Apollo. The priceless library must well be worth a visit. It now contains 10,000 volumes, including many rare additions, and specimens of early printing. Among the numerous and valuable MS preserved in the archives, are the commentary of Origen on the epistle to the Romans, dating from the 6th century - splendidly illuminated MSS, documents of kings, popes, etc. bulls, letters etc. There now remain in this convent 30 monks who share the charge of the library and archives, and educate theological students. After taking possession of our rooms, we drove
to the bankers for letters, and then over to St. Peters. Rome is changing fast. Within the two years since we have been here, whole quarters have been destroyed - streets have been made - bridges built - and square after square of handsome new houses. Old Rome indeed threatens to be improved from off the face of the earth. Much is to be said for and against these wholesale changes. There is great gain in the way of health and convenience - many invaluable remains are brought to the light in the necessary excavations - important historical facts verified - and the general appearance of the city will be vastly improved. But very much of the old charm and interesting character is lost. All those rows of picturesque houses dipping their foundations in the flood of the yellow Tiber, which gave such a charm to the banks of the river, are now being decourously tucked away and hidden beyond the solid and handsome stone quays now building on both sides of the river. We all burst into a howl of indignation however, when we came to the Ponte S. Angelo, to see a modern iron suspension bridge thrusting itself within a stones toss of the S. Angelo! and it is said a bridge of the same kind is to be thrown across the Forum! What a sense of satisfied delight one feels, when the heavy curtain of S. Pietro falls behind one, and one confronts all the colossal magnificence of this unequalled church! Far away in the vast expanse rises the great bronze baldachine, with its circle of twinkling lights before it, and pigmies of human beings come and go, and arrange themselves in groups over that vast tesselated pavement - and a low muffled reverberation characteristic of the place, compounded of shuffling footsteps and distant
chanting, and outside roar and turmoil, makes itself felt rather than heard. Mary walked about in a maze of delight. It is such a charm to find myself again in Rome - every sight of the streets is dear to me.

We went this morning to the Capitol, and saw the bronzes, and new Capitoline collection composed of objects found in the excavations of recent years, then to the church of the Capuchins to see the beautiful St. Michael of Guido Reni - Mary and Theodore went down to see the old dead monks, and their bones, which, having once seen, I preferred sitting in the carriage in the warm fresh air. In the afternoon we went to the Respigliosa Palace to see Guido Reni's lovely Aurora, and then to the church of S. Lorenzo in Lucina to see his crucifiction - but all the pounding and ringing that we could do, did not open the church to us - so quite disgusted, we climbed again into the carriage, and drove to St. Peters.

This morning we went to S. Paolo fuori le Mura - a deadly cold magnificent uninteresting church - the only thing that reconciles me to a visit there, are the cloisters, with their pretty fanciful twisted and fluted double columns. Then we tried the Pantheon, and found it closed - before which, after leaving S. Paolo, we went to the lovely English cemetery, against the old walls of Rome, near the pyramid
tomb of Caius Castius. Its solemn yew trees, amongst which the birds were singing, and underneath the flowers were blooming on the quiet graves, made us say as we always do on that spot, that we would rather be buried there, than anywhere else. Then we drove to the grounds of the Villa Borghese, and saw King Umberto driving in a plain victoria, and the Queen in her carriage with her scarlet liveries.

Drove this morning to the Baths of Caracalla, which I had not seen for 7 years - and I walked about everywhere, amazed at such mighty ruins. Then we drove to the Lateran, which is almost as cold and uninteresting as S. Paola fuori le PuraMura. In the afternoon we made a visit to Signor Castellani, and Theodore bought some lovely presents. Then we went to a sale of antiquities, and Mary and I did a little private shopping.

Being the feast of the Annunciation we went to S. Maria Sopra Minerva, where we were told we would hear some fine singing. There was not singing, but some lovely organ music. I found among the congregation Miss Wood and here sister of Colombus, and Maria Gwynne, who told me that she and Marie Glockren were here at the Eden Hotel - so I arranged to visit them at 5 o'clock - and after an afternoon at St. Peters with the most exquisite sacred music I
ever listened to, given by the Papal choir in the Sistine Chapel, I drove to the Eden to see my cousins - and shared a rather unsatisfactory visit, with a huge Monsignon some body to whom Marie introduced me - and who seemed to find satisfaction in contradicting everything that was said.

Theodore and Mary went to the picture gallery of the Vatican this morning, but it being too much for me, I drove about, and then went to fetch them dead as they were with fatigue. In the afternoon we made a visit to the Forum - which smelled very awfully indeed, and I did not think we ought to stay, but we did, until after 5 o'clock. I met there my old Weisbaden friends and fellow boarders, Miss Knee of England, and Miss Johnston of Edinburg. We knew each other at once. They are at Marini's and like it very much - I was very tired when we got home.
In the house all day - resting, writing and amusing myself. Theodore and Mary hard at work outside.

Drove over to the Vatican early, and left T. and Mary at the Gallery of Sculpture. It is always a great pleasure to drive around the great church to this entrance, and through the lane leading past the carriage houses of the Vatican, with the gardens looking down upon them from the opposite side, and the huge pile of the Vatican Palace soaring above and around. It is such utterly inaccessible ground, that my interest and curiosity are always fired. Driving back to the city it was funny to see the almost uninterrupted line of carriages setting towards St. Peters, filled with tourists and red Baddekers. I spent an hour and a half hunting photographs, and buying some trifles, and then went back for T. and M. In the afternoon we made our third ineffectual attempt to get into S. Lorenzo in Lucina to see Guido Reni'sCrucifixion, and then went to the Parthenon - afterwards driving up to the Villa Pamphilja Doria, and home by way of the new gardens and drives of the Villa Corsini, past the beautiful fountain of S. Paola and enjoying once more the matchless views of Rome, which these terraces and drives give.

We spent the morning at the Capitol in the Gallery of sculpture - afterwards T. and M. climbed up the stairs to the interesting church of Ara Coali, which being too much for me, I sat in the carriage and tried to look as if I neither heard nor saw the beggars that clamoured about me. In the afternoon we drove up to the little old church of S. Sabina, among the vine clad hills - standing in a quiet left alone corner, and saw once more Sassoferrato's beautiful Madonna of the Rosary. Then we went on to the interesting Priorata. How vividly the last time I saw it came to me - and poor Charlie Wilson was with us!

Being told we would hear some grand music at the LatoranLateran church, we provided ourselves with camp stools, and drove there. As is customary in Holy Week, no organ was played. The music was good but simple, but there was little satisfaction in listening to it, in such a moving shuffling crowd - and the church as deadly cold, so we soon came away, and went into the Baptistry, a much more interesting place - then - having an hour before luncheon, we drove to S. Clementi and to S. Prassodo, and then to S. Pudenziana, all of which, Nellie and I saw most thoroughly two winters ago. In the afternoon we went over to St. Peters to hear the low mass - the music most solemn and beautiful - no organ - I walked all about the great church, and took farewell views of all my favorite points, and drove home regretfully. I have never been in Rome when the weather was so warm before. Our windows have been open most of the time - no fires necessary - and the sun excluded. The flowers now are most lovely and plentiful.
Our last day in Rome has been very busy - Theodore and Mary went to the Borghese gallery - and visiting, driving and shopping and packing have filled up the day.

We breakfasted early this morning, and left Rome at 8.30 - reaching here at 3 o'clock P.M. - after a charming ride. Tuscany is
very beautiful. I have never seen it so late as this - everything green - the streets filled with lovely flowers for sale. We wanted to go back to our old quarters at the Hotel de la Ville, but could not get them.

We took Mary this morning for her first visit to the Uffizi. In consideration of my lameness, we committed ourselves to the elevator, and paid a franc apiece for the transit to those lofty galleries - and a dangerous one it seemed, worked with an ordinary rope cable, and bumping and knocking from side to side, and making the strangest noises. When we came away, I preferred to climb down those stony staircases, rather than trust myself to it again. We spent two and a half hours in these incomparable galleries, before we emerged more dead than alive. In the afternoon we drove to S. Miniato, which always delights me. I like to sit down on the parapet at the edge of the terrace, and look at the church, rich and lovely, with its inlaid marbles tones and yellowed by age. It is of the Pisan Florentine style, not unlike S. Maria Novella, and the hideous and fantastic Italian cemetery which surrounds it cannot detract from its charm. Next to it, and apparently part of it is the old machicolated Mozzi Palace. S. Miniato is one of my favorite spots in Florence, and when I am tired of looking at the church I can turn and look at the fortifications built by Michael Angelo, through the gateway of which we approach the church - and to the noble
view of the lovely city, spread out far below us - the Arno glistening in silver curves away in the distance, and, surrounded by that grand sweep of hills and mountains, Florence, with the great dome of Brunelleschi, and Giotto's Tower, and the more graceful campanile of the Palazzo Vecchio, towering over the other domes and lesser campaniles and stately palaces and picturesque bridges. Its beauty is all its own, - and it looks so small - even in glorious days when , intellectually and artistically, it ruled the world, and of the fierce dissensions and cruel wars and brutal turmoils, that surged about within its very walls for centuries - of which the great palaces, more like fortifications than palaces, are now the only witnesses.

The cemetery here at S. Miniato seems to overflow into the church, and little railings and photographs and artificial flowers and mimic trees surround the tomb stones here as well as outside, and make a kind of Campo Santo of the whole place. The interior arrangement is peculiar - and the pavement and marble work of the choir, is of the 13th century and very beautiful and curious. From S. Miniato we drove to S. Croce, where a service was going on, with some solemn and delicious music - the church in a half twilight, with the twinkling lights of the altars, with its simple and noble proportions, was more impressive than I have ever seen it - and the tombs of Italy's mighty dead - Dante, Michael Angelo, Galileo etc. smite one with feelings of awe. It was a lovely visit.

We started off this morning to the Pitti galleries, across the river, and spent two hours or more in that stately palace - looking at the finest pictures any gallery in the world contains - then walked through the interminable galleries and corridors lending to the uffizi, which, with the exception of the engravings has no interest for me - but the views from the windows, over the roofs of the houses, and down into unexpected little courts, and out upon the river, and the graceful bridges, are all full of charm. We stopped at the flower market as we came home, which was a sight worth seeing, and brought away loads of fragrant beauties. In the afternoon to various places, and to S. Annunciata to hear some music. It being Maundy Thursday, the streets were alive with people, and very gay, and the churches crowded.

Drove to the Medici Chapel of S. Lorenzo and spent almost an hour there with the mighty creations of Michael Angelo - never have they seemed to wonderful to me. Then we went to S. Marco, to the cloisters and monastery and home in time for lunch. In the afternoon we went to the Accademia to see the old painting and the David, and the Lucca Della Robbias, and drove to the Cascine - it was cold however for driving - and rain is much needed, and the dust flying - but most brilliant sunshine every day.

I drove Theodore and Mary over to the Pitti this morning, but did not venture in myself. I went to some shops, and to the interesting chruch of Or San Michele - a little service was going on, and I sat down on one of the empty benches, and read my book, and examined the details of the wonderful shrine of Orcagna, built for Ugolino's sacred picture of the miraculous Madonna, in 1359. The picture was veiled of course, this being Holy Week, so that I could not see it - but I walked all around the shrine, in spite of the service going on in the chancel close by - one grows so soon accustomed to these things in Italy. The windows of this church are exquisite in tracery and stained glass. I had myself driven twice about the church, in order to see the admirable statues with which it is adorned - among which Donatello's famous St. George is the finest - a noble and lovely thing. The whole church in its limited space, is framed in by buildings of most mediaeval and picturesque interest.

Mary and I went to the pretty American church, across the river this morning - it was exquisitely trimmed with flowers, and the service was very good - and so was the singing. I was conveniently near the door, and just before the sermon I came out, and drove alone to the Cascine - I was in hope I would find Theodore somewhere, so that I might take him with me, but I had the whole park to myself, and
it was delicious - the birds singing, and the air so fresh and fragrant. In doors all the afternoon.

A visit to the Bargello this morning, and then to lunch with the >Morgan Morgans in their charming house in Giardino Torrigianni - after which, Mary and I went to S. Maria Novella, and tried to get into La Badia to see the cloisters, but failed, as the church was closed. Then we looked at photographs at Brogi's - and in the evening, the Van Renssaelaer party came in and visited us.

This morning after breakfast we drove to the Badia, with the same ill success as on yesterday - then to S. Croce for a last visit, then left Mary at the Uffizi for an hour and a half, sending back the carriage for her - while I went home and did some last packing - and we were off by half past 2 o'clock in a coupe by ourselves for Milan, which we reached this evening by 10.30. We breakfast early tomorrow, and leave in the 9:40 train for Lucerne.

After breakfast this morning, Theodore took Mary for a short visit to the Cathedral, then they came back for me. We found on reaching
the station, that Theodore had written and engaged chairs in the "drawing room car" - and delightful it was, with its big windows and so much space - so that the splendid ride over the St. Gotthard was more beautiful than I have ever seen it - and it was the third journey I had made over it! We found at the top, a great deal of snow falling, the ground covered, and trees laden with it, such superb effects! We arrived about 4 o'clock. I am always so pleased to see again the pretty meadows and chalets on this side the Alps - and Lucerne has for me many charms. This incomparable hotel is now full. Our sitting room looks out upon the lake, and we found a bright fire burning in it, looking most home-like - for it is really cold - the snow is lying upon the hills and mountains, and forms a great contrast to the views on the southern side of the Alps. Como was lovely this morning as we skirted along its shores - the blue water crisp with white crests for a stiff wind was blowing. I never saw such a deep pink in the blossoms of the peach trees, which were scattered all over the meadows, and through the vineyards - and the violets actually made blue patches in the landscape - while every hill side and meadow was yellow with cowslips, even on this side near Lucerne. The great dining room was open and the two long tables this evening, full of guests.

I was in despair this morning when I looked out of my window at 7 o'clock - the snow lying thickly on everything, and a miserable rain falling - no mountains to be seen, and the lake, a gray mist.
I know the lovely features so well - but my disappointment was for Mary's sake, whom I wanted to show a glimpse of Swiss scenery. We have been sitting about the fire ever since breakfast grumbling at the weather - at one moment asserting it was going to clear, and the next declaring despairingly that it was not. But we hope for better things this afternoon, as our train for Basle does not leave before 5 o'clock.

Arrived this morning at 7 o'clock after a wretched night in a sleeping car, full of smoking men - could not get to bed until 12 o'clock because of the Douane at Delle on the frontier. The rain yesterday at Lucerne continuted to fall steadily - and in despair we got into a little cab and drove to a bric-a-brac shop that we remembered visiting before. Found a very few good things - enormously dear - Theodore bought a curious and interesting ivory cup - turned by a a well known Nürnberg artist of the 17th century. After luncheon Theodore and Mary took a little walk, the rain having slackened, to see the famous lions of Thorwaldsen's, and the old bridge while I sat comfortably by the fire, and read my book. At 5 o'clock we took the train for Basle, where we had an excellent supper at the station, and then got into our sleeping car. The weather in Paris is cold and wet. Mary and I began the inevitable shopping career this afternoon. We were surprised to find that Annie and Sara were not here, neither was there a letter from them.

A busy week with shop and dressmakers was happily closed. The weather has been very wet and cold. We have done nothing that is interesting. One evening we went to the Opera and heard Faust splendidly sung by Madame Melba, and the brothers Derenscke - all superb artists - grand ballet etc. I grew very tired before the evening was over. We have been in a quondary about Mrs. Davis - as she has been quite ill at Biarritz - yesterday Sara Buttles telegraphed she was much better, and would come on to Paris this week. We will probably get off to London on Tuesday. This evening Mr. Kimber called and soon after Dr. Cecil Austin - and they are just gone.

div.dateline: London- Longs Hotel - Bond St. Tuesday, April 22.
div.p: We left Paris this morning at 10 o'clock via Boulogne and Falkestone, and arrived at the hotel about 6 p.m. leaving Theodore at the station with the luggage, to go through the vexations of the Custom House. It has rained persistently most of the day - our crossing was disagreeable - but we had an excellent state room, and I made myself comfortable on a lounge, and slept most of the way over.

The days have flown by - the weather bad - dark and raining most of the time. It is pleasant to be in London once more - in spite of smoke and fog, and too, too frequent rain, it is charming. Mr. Rathbone
called on Thursday - and Friday morning we met him at Agnews, where we had gone to see the strange and beautiful drawings of the "Legend of the Briar Rose" by Burne Jones - in a series of four pictures. The rooms were beautifully trimmed with flowers - it was the first morning of the exhibition, and if we had waited until the afternoon, we would have seen a lot of notable people, Mr. Gladstone among others.

On Friday, we went to Minton's and chose some beautiful new china. On Saturday morning Mr Gaspard Farrar called, and asked Theodore to dinner, where he is this evening. Then we walked around to Vigo Street to the two little silver shops, and at one of them Theodore bought some charming old silver platters and trays. Then to Dunthoran's gallery, where in his pretty rooms we saw a lot of beautiful etchings by William Strange - one of which Theodore bought. Here the sun which had been fitfully shining, disappeared - and a yellow fog, which afterwards became black rapidly fell upon us - and in a few moments it was too dark to see to read on the street. There was nothing for it but to get into a four wheeler, detestable things, and come home, and wait for better things, which didn"t come - and Mary and I stayed in doors the rest of the day. There were the strange lurid, ominous effects so often seen in the London atmosphere, and Mary seemed to think it a special show got up for her amusement. In the afternoon Mr. David Milliken of New York who is staying in the house made us a long visit, and afterwards Mr. Lidderdale, the Governor of the Bank of England called - and was as delightful as he always is.

On Wednesday everning we went to see Irving and Ellen Terry in the "Dead Heart", a weak drama of the French Revolution times. Irving was especially weak in it, and only Miss Terry saved the play from utter flatness. On Friday evening we went to the Court Theatre to see Mrs John Woods company in the amusing comedy of "The Prime Minister" which we much enjoyed. This morning I stayed in doors and wrote letters, and in the afternoon Mary and I went down to service at Westminster Abbey - we were early, but we found it crowded, and could only hear a word now and then, of the service or the sermon. I took a quiet little nap, and interested myself in a monument near me of the Duke of Newcastle, a large on in excellent taste, with recumbent effigies of the Duke and his Duchess lying side by side. I had time to commit to memory the following epitaph.

"Here lyeth the loyall Duke of Newcastle and his Dutchess, who was "his second wife, and bywhom he had no issue, her name was Margaret Lucas, youngest sister to the Lord Lucas of Calchester, a noble familie, "of which all the Brothers were valiant, and all the sisters virtuous. "This Dutchess was a wise, witty and learned lady, as her numerous "Bookes do well testify - she was a loving and faithful and a careful "wife and accompanied her husband in all his banishments and miseries, " and when he came home never left him in solitary retirement."

Soon after getting home, Theodore came in with Mr. Milliken and telling them about the service, I repeated the epitaph. Mr. Milliken then told me of a tombstone he had seen in Indiana, with this inscription.
"Here lyeth George Smith. His next neighbor played the cornet."

div.dateline: Sunday morning, May 4th. Bull Hotel - Cambridge.
div.p: A week ago since I found time to write in my journal, during which week time has been racing along, and we have been vainly trying to keep up with it. Pictures and art galleries - visits and shopping have occupied us. One evening we went with Mr Rathbone to dine at the Savoy Restaurant, and went to see the play of Dr. Bill at the Avenue Theatre afterwards - an amusing, but rather broad farce. We spent a delightful morning at the Abbey, saw a spring flower show, went to the "first view" of the Academy, for which we had tickets sent us through the kindness of friends. Day before yesterday was a very busy day, a lot of people coming in in the morning, among them Mr. Dunthorne with a lovely little basket of primroses and forget-me-nots fresh from the country. We spent one afternoon at the British Museum, Theodore taking down his papyrus for repairs and translation, and having the courage to send his sphynx afterwards to the Egyptian department for examination as to its age and genuinness. We looked through the Egyptian things with great interest. Yesterday we left London for this place, having arranged with Mr Lüling an undergraduate here about our visit. He met us at the station on our arrival and after coming to the Hotel with us for awhile came back to dine with us, and spent the evening.

Sunday evening. A charming day is done. The weather has been delightful. We began the day by walking at half past 10 o'clock with Mr. Lüling through the "Backs" as the meadows lying back of the colleges are called. The freshness of the young foliage - the flowers - the birds - all made a picture of spring beauty - we walked through Kings, Trinity, Clare Colleges, and went to Mr. Lüling's rooms for lunch, where we met a friend of his, Mr. Fielding a younger son of the Earl of Denhigh. A most delightful young fellow. Then I went home for a rest, while the rest went for service at King's Chapel. I was sorry not to see this - but I had a splitting headache. At 4 o'clock Mary and Constance Austin went to Mrs. George Darwin's, a friend of Constance's, for afternoon tea, and Mr. Lüling came to take me and Theodore to Mr. Fieldings rooms in Trinity College, where we were to have tea - pleasant rooms, and simple unaffected fellows. The Mr. Fieldings who had secured places for us in the Chapel for afternoon service, walked across the Quad with us - without anything on his head. He and Lüling, who is a member of Trinity Hall, and both Roman Catholics, did not attend chapel, but on coming out Mr. F. came down from the organ gallery with the organist, where he had been during the service - he is very musical. We had a lovely service, and the famous great organ - and all the men coming in in their white gowns, looked as if they might be a congregation of angels. Then after a stroll through the gardens and meadows in the sweet evening light, the young men walked back to the Bull with us, Mr. F. without his hat or gown, and we were hoping to see a proctor light upon him. Then we all went to Lüling's rooms for high tea, and spent
a nice good evening in pleasant talk. The young men walked back to the hotel with us, and we declared when they had said goodbye, that we have never seen two such nice boys.

We brought our pleasant and all too short visit to London to an end this afternoon - leaving there at 4.30. We looked longingly at Winchester as we came by, but hoped to see it tomorrow as our S.S. is not expected until afternoon. We left Cambridge last Monday morning, and were soon plunged into London engagements and business. Theodore and I did some necessary shopping, and Constance and Mary went to the Royal Society of Water Colours. In the evening Theodore and I dined with the Lidderdales - a trifle heavy - but as I know so little about English society I always feel like assisting in a novel, when I go into it - and like to study the people. Mr. L. was as delightful as he always is.

The next day Constance left us to pay a visit to some friends just outside London. In the evning Theodore, Mary and I dined with Sir William and Lady Farrar. We had a charming evening, though I was too tired to talk much. Lady Farrar in the midst of her large family of grown sons and daughters, was as sweet an English matron, as one would wish to see.

The next day Wednesday, was a breathless rush of packing, and doing last things. Gaspard Farrar came in the afternoon to say
goodbye. The Le Roy Kings too, bringing me some lovely flowers - and Mr. Lidderdale. In the evening we drove to Chelsea to dine with Mr. Rathbone and his sister-in-law Miss Lüling, and had a charming evening - and the next day Thursday was another rush until we left for Southampton. We found Mrs. Davis and Miss Buttles here - the former looking very ill - and now Mary and I am sitting in a dismal heavy sitting room, feeing that the fair is over, and prosaic things now await us.

Just a week ago, we left Southampton, and we should have been in New York by this time, had we not met with so much fog. For two days and nights the fog whistle has been going most of the time, making sleep at night almost impossible. The voyage has been quiet and uneventful. We have had one hard blow. The big ship 460 feet long is, next to the City of Paris, the fastest on the ocean. Mary and I have a big room, with wardrobe, with mirrored door - table - lounge etc. but in spite of the comforts and luxuries, I have never felt more wretched on the Atlantic. There has not been much motion, but what there was, was all in the way of pitching - rising and falling - the most trying of all motions. The voyage has seemed interminable. One day we saw 3 icebergs - and if the course had been the usual one, no doubt we would have been in the midst of icebergs. But on the last voyage to Southampton, such an extent of field ice,
and so many ice bergs were passed, that, on the voyage the Captain took a very southerly course. Our progress has been as follows:

First day (21-½ hours 418 miles.
2d " 461 "
3d " 459 "
4th " (heavy gales) 439 "
5th " (fog) 442 "
6th " " 470 "

We were still in a dense fog and reported to be 40 miles from Sandy Hook (10 o'clock A.M.). We have not yet found a pilot, and are scarcely moving through the thick fog - sounding our whistle every moment. Should this fog lift, we would easily be in New York by noon - allowing for quarantine etc. but as we will surely be in today, I now close this little record of the winter's travel, feeling assured that the pleasure of future reference to it, will more than atone for all the time I have given to it.
